description:
Cool bar with colorful lights. Chill vibes. 

Margaritas flavored, was so sweet.

A crowd during midnight bar hours!  

Themed artwork all around. 

Exploring the Mission bars!
author: Tiffany D.

description:
I love how dark (and red) it is in here. 

I opted not to drink, but the atmosphere was lovely.

We literally just had bratwurst, walked over for pizza, and while we were waiting for our pizza order, some of my cousins had drinks here.

The bartender came to our table and asked for my ID (I think that's great that they actually check).  And although all my cousins already ordered their drinks, she asked if she could get me anything. 

There's plenty of booths, tables, seats at the bar, and some couch seating arrangements. We went pretty early on a Saturday so it wasn't packed at all, but it was getting more bar patrons as our stay was ending.
author: Lilian L.

description: This place looks a bit dirty from outside but it's a comfy dive with reasonable priced drinks and bartenders are low-key and chill. Been here a couple times and it's always been easy going and somewhere to sit and talk
author: Morethankimchi J.

description:
If you're looking for a getaway from busy Blondies across the street come here! That's how we discovered it...long ass lines are only fun for so long haha. 

If I was looking for a mellow night I'd give more stars, but it was a little too low key for our night. Could hardly hear the music! 

Better for lounging in the dim corner on a date. I mean if you're into dive bars that is.... :)
author: Heather H.

description:
If you're looking for a dark bar decorated with vintage velvet titty art that serves up a mighty mean greyhound, Casanova Lounge is exactly the place for you. 

I'd say no frills but those velvet pieces of art are just too 'extra' to be considered anything but. And how many dive bars do you know that juice their grapefruits old school style at the bar? They've got personality, they've got questionable class, and they've certainly got style. 

One of my favorite bars in the city and yet a bar consistently forget the name of until after I'm in and my eyes have adjusted to the darkness I realize I'm surround by Johnny Cash and walls of timeless nipples staring back at me.
author: Candice G.

description: Yep, still the worst bar on Valencia. The bartenders here are so stupid. They just don't look up and see whose next. The literal definition of, well we probably cant say that here on yelp by you know. To the bartenders at Casanova, you suck.
author: Stare D.

description:
Dear Yelp, It's me again. I am writing to you with regard to a small establishment of questionable ilk called the Casanova Lounge. I have been on assignment as what is known as a "secret shopper" for the past 16 years. I must update you on a small matter of growing concern - the beard of Chris. It has become quite unruly and I see fit to report it to the Better Business Beard-o (see what I did there?). I give his beard 3 of 5 stars, but 2 of those are pity stars. So please adjust my rating according. Good day to you, Yelp. 

PS. I am back on assignment as a secret shopper. After roughly twelve dozen visits I missed provide an addendum to my earlier review. 

First, Chris Campasi "Make me week in he knees-y" is definitely the go to barkeep. Dude can duck, jive, crossover, and isn't afraid to take the shot. I've seen this dude drain 3 pointers with a broken clavicle and fractured ribs on a Tuesday. A TUESDAY. Yep. He brings his A game to your fantasy football league. So head down to Casanova. Ask for Chris. And have him make you one of his famous slippery nipples or spritzers.
author: Matt M.

description: Better than most of the nearby establishments. Kudos for the sexy black velvet artwork. Good music. Relatively spacious. Nice and dark.
author: Patrick S.

description: Do you believe in love at first sight? I've just fallen in love with my favorite bar! It's got a great decor of 60's 70's lighting, and a great mix of people! The walls are covered in framed nudes on velvet! Ignoring it's convenient location, I would make the trip here over and over!
author: Douglas A.

description:
If i could give less of a star i would. The bouncers are trash and seem to create there own rules when they have nothing better to do, my friends and I were enjoying a night out and apparently the bouncer was under the impression I had outside liquor brought in. After telling him I didn't he insisted on searching my bag which was a complete invasion of privacy. I mean, please, you're not law enforcement..
After being asked to leave I had already made the assumption that this is not a place for those going for an after work drink, or even a place to enjoy the start of my weekend. Don't waist your time, you get what you pay for.
author: Cody B.

description: Cool dive bar in the mission with neekid pictures of ladies on all the walls. Crowded, fun, comfy couches, and I like how they decorated the place. Drinks are made strong.
author: Matthew P.

description: Fun and good crowd. I avoid at all costs on Fridays though--best late at night on weekdays!
author: Perry C.

description: I came to this bar with a friend of mine just yesterday. When we first got there it was a really cool ambiance. The guy at the door was really nice and we got our seats at the bar. There was a guy next to me so I started having a conversation with him. It turned "political" but in no way was it getting out of hand. One of the bartenders, I don't know her name but she was a bigger girl with a lot of tattoos came over to us and started telling me I was harassing the guy I was talking to and told me I needed to leave.I don't want to call her out on being racist but I am a black woman and she seemed uncomfortable with me speaking my truth.  She was being super unprofessional and rude to me for no reason. I ended up leaving but it was so out of pocket that I would never go back and make sure everyone I know never goes as well. If you can't even handle to hear a genuine conversation then maybe don't get a job where people come from different points of view.
author: Kailah P.

description: Classic San Francisco dive bar. Vintage decore and suitable drinks. Gets crowded later.
author: David H.

description: Dopest dope I ever smoked. Come on through and see how they do. Happy hour is the happiest, similar to hugging a mermaid.
author: Robert M.

description: One of my favorite bars in the mission. Has a silverlake vibe but in a good way. Stay for the greyhounds and cool decor. Good place to chill and talk with friends. Stay gritty, Casanova!
author: Caitlin G.

description:
Nope, not for me. There are plenty of bars in the Mission and this one ranks ultra low for me. 

The Moscow Mule I had was not that great. The place was very grungy and made me uncomfortable. I'm going to say no if anyone suggests this place in the future.
author: Yi Z.

description: I left my wallet at the lounge and the bartenders we're nice enough to find it and save it for me when I frantically came back hoping it was still there. Everything was still in the wallet AND I tried to give them a tip and they wouldn't accept it; only requesting that I come visit again :)., Doesn't get any better than that. Love the people here.
author: Derrick M.

description: The best thing about this place is the ambiance. It's dark and has very cool decor (lanterns, black velvet paintings, couches.) There isn't much seating relative to the amount of people there, and there's also not much standing room. It says you can make a reservation, but I called several times over a 3-day period, left a message, and sent 2 emails. I did not hear back from them until well after I gave up and already went there. They say reservations are for groups of 8+, but I was told that a group of ten was too much for one reservation. It was a very opaque and confusing process that I didn't even hear back about until several days later. I'd say don't bother with a reservation, just show up and wait around until you can swoop a table. The well drinks were really overpriced and it was unclear how to request drinks with higher quality liquor. It was challenging for a first time visitor. I'm sure it's fine if you're with 3 people and know every drink option, but if you're a first-time visitor it'll take a bit to figure this place out.
author: M. S.

description: I like Casanova Lounge, it was especially nice to come here on a rainy day and cozy up in the booth (during happy hour).  This place is filled with mission hipsters sipping on beer and the whole atmosphere is fairly relaxing.  There are a few TVs and some interesting nude artwork on the walls to talk about over a few good beers.  At happy hour the bar seems to get a bit overwhelmed with only one staff member and a pretty full crowd, but nothing too insane.  A nice place that is different to its neighboring bars on Valencia.
author: Kelsey B.

description:
Casanova is a mix between an old-school dive bar and a swanky lounge. Either way, you're bound to find yourself cozied up in their lush leather couches or on a stool at the bar. For a Wednesday night they were pretty busy! I'd suggest getting in here between the hours of 4-7pm to take advantage of their happy hour - $1 off any drink!

Cheers!
author: Sarin P.

description:
I like this place because the bartenders are nice and they have really cool lighting. 

I can't say much else as I'm usually on one by the time I get to Cassanova. One time I met my chef friend there with some of his co-workers and it was a cool time, but then one of the girls at our table told me "good luck" right as she was leaving, and I was really thrown off. 

The end.
author: Crystal C.

description: Good great fun ,bartenders are cool an seasoned nice art on the walls and good seating
author: Casey M.

description:
This place deserves five out of five stars, except for tonight. My friend and I frequent this place whenever we want a good margarita or mixed drink, (Nick is the best bartender!), but tonight after getting a few rounds, we stopped to get ice cream before returning and were suddenly carded at the door. This would not have been a problem if the guy at the door had actually carded me at the door. I was making a bee line for the restroom when I suddenly felt a rude tap on my shoulder. The guy who was standing by the door demanded that I show him my ID even though I was practically at the bathroom. After showing him my ID (my friend was holding my purse outside while she smoked a cigarette) and him giving me sass (albeit, I asked him if my ID would suffice in an annoyed manner), I refused to re-enter the bar on principle as he said I was not being an adult bc I was frustrated for being carded halfway to the bathroom (I was not stopped when I entered as he was chatting with his friend at the door and was not doing his job) 

I understand that you were "just doing your job", but it seems interesting that you doing your job entails stopping folks walking to the goddamn bathroom. If I had been ordering a drink, I would understand. And I had intended to do so, but after this experience, I am not sure when I will return to this bar. I would even understand if you had carded me at the door, but stopping me on my way to the bathroom and being rude to me really ruined my otherwise pleasant evening at this bar.
author: Ashley M.

description:
Tl;dr version: great bar that has kept it real for decades 
----

The Diet Coke can you've been kicking up Valencia Street for the last quarter mile straddles the edge of the sewer hole briefly then plummets into the darkness. Creatures down below can be heard rushing to examine it. Seeing if there is flesh to chew off. 

"That's unfortunate," your robot traveling companion remarks in his digital voice. "You seemed to have derived great pleasure from the continuous foot-pushing of that aluminum container." 

You're probably just projecting, but you swear you hear sadness in Merkyl's voice. You'll never understand why this person Jeff Bezos built a sentient robot to look like it was made out of cardboard boxes. But that's Merkyl. He saved you from a pack of terror-owls while you were scavenging in Golden Gate park and you've been traveling together ever since. 
You look around the ruins of what once must have been a vibrant and majestic city. 

You were born after The Event, when a madman took over the Large Hadron Collider in Geneva, Switzerland and used it to make Orange Chicken, opening up portals to horrible dimensions and flooding the earth with chaos and destruction http://bit.ly/29O7FOd 

"Merkyl, is this the place you were telling me about?" you ask. "Didn't you used to tell jokes or something around here?"

"Long form improvisational comedy," he replies. 

"Well do something now!" you cheer excitedly. 

"It does not work like that," he says flatly. "I would require a one word suggestion along with my improvisational comedy partner...Derkyl."

You swear you hear it again. That sadness. You decide to change topics. 

"Did you ever go to this uhhhh..." You're buying time as you rummage around. Then you spot it. You pull the billboard up from the rubble. "You ever go to this Casanova place?"

"Yes. I enjoyed the lack of pretension while Derkyl enjoyed the paintings of naked female humans."

Merkyl is searching through the wreckage of Casanova with purpose. 

"Hey Merkyl," rushes out in a single breathe. You didn't plan to do this, but it's happening. "Whatever happened to Derkyl?" 

Your robot friend freezes. That weird jumper cable around its torso sparks.

"We shall see. All simulations result in an expiration."

He looks back at you then drags a big slab on concrete to open up a makeshift tomb. You see another cardboard robot, who you can only assume to be Derkyl. His unexpressive eyes light up. 

"Merkyl?" Derkyl asks.

"Yes." Merkly replies.

"Jeff Bezos?"

"Fuck that guy."

"Fuck that guy."

"Fuck that guy."

"Fuck that guy."

The telepathic squirrel on your shoulder becomes overwhelmed with emotion and faints. 

Your forearm sears in pain and the fourth out of seven outlines of stars fills in with branded flesh. The last time that happened was after you killed a demonic god, so you know this is an incredibly important moment http://bit.ly/29TbqSZ

You watch Merkyl and Derkyl as they attempt what you assume is a hug. It's clunky. You look at the new marking on your arm, and for a moment, indulge in the thought giving up on your quest. You think about shedding the responsibility to save all worlds across every dimension. Then you see Merkyl and Derkyl talking while pretending to eat unopened cans of soup and you can't help but smile. And you decide it's worth it.
author: Dave G.

description: Love everything. Gay friendly . Super nice staff. I didn't feel judged or out of norm
author: Kiana L.

description:
I've been to this bar before and my friends really liked their Midori sours and the ambiance.  This past weekend I went back for my birthday and my friend who is Hawaii wasn't let in nor his partner. I'm guessing it's because a lot of people have fakes from Hawaii so he tried showing the bouncer his credit cards that is also Hawaiin in order to prove he was actually from there. However, because my friend is gay they began to mock him. 

When my friend asked him what his problem was, another bouncer began to film us with his cellphone even though we weren't provoking anyone. It was still early in the night and no one was intoxicated yet. I can't stand for homophobia so I will never be back.
author: Mariana L.

description:
Came here for a night cap after a date night and was immediately drawn in by the decor.
I loved the vibe of this place -- cool music, cozy setting with an artsy flair and standard bar drinks.

Cozy booths provide for an intimate setting in the over crowded SF bar scene these days. 

Conversation over house music any day, and you will absolutely get that here.
author: Taylor O.

description: Came here for a happy hour celebrating a coworkers last day and it was really fun! I've always preferred lounges over bars in regards to atmosphere and Casanova dos the trick with a cheap, but great drink selection and the loungey atmosphere. Definitely a fan!
author: Quinn Li O.

description: I'm on crutches. I was hanging out there late night and wanted to wait ~5 min on their seat for my friend to pick me up during closing time and they kicked me out. Had to stand on one leg on crutches for those 5 min.
author: Hratch B.

description:
Depending when you go here, this place can get super busy, so fair warning.

I've been here a few times. I like the ambiance and the atmosphere of the place. There's a bar area to chill/stand/sit at, but there's also comfy lounge chairs (and some small tables) scattered around. The decor is something else. It was very... er... unique. Not bad, but just different, which is good if you're looking for a change from the usual.

The bar staff is usually friendly, but when it gets busy here, they definitely seem overwhelmed. Don't be surprised if you have to wait a looong time for a drink. 

I came here last year for Mardi Gras, and there was a little show that was put on, which was fun to watch, but can be a bit awkward if (like me) you ended up at one of the front table seats and then have to try not to get smacked in the face.

Overall, a good place that I'm sure I'll be back to again. It's probably not my go-to place, but I do have a good time when I go there
author: Bianca C.

description:
Cool place to go in, get a drink, get out. I suppose it is also fun to just mingle because it is a small place and cozy enough to bump into people and get a casual conversation started. Don't like it? Then get out and go to the next bar. 

We ordered the margaritas because we realized that is what mostly everyone was getting. It was okay. Got the drink, hung out, got out.
author: Mayra E.

description:
Worst place in SFO! These people have anger management problems. My friend was asking for drinks and they were very rude. When he finally got his drinks and the check he didn't left a tip and instead he wrote in spanish: "Me caiste mal" = "I didn't like you". The bartender went crazy and he came with 2 guys from security, they pushed him and hit him on his hand so he could drop his drink. They started screaming "we know you wrote F$&% you, get the f$&% out! My friend tried to calm then down but they were insane!! We all left immediately and security started pushing us outside telling us all we couldn't even be in that street. They were rude even to the girls.

This people are crazy!! Don't even think about going there
author: Carol P.

description:
Dim
Red lights,
Naked dames
Poorly painted
And crowds with so so drinks. A touch too loud.
author: Justin L.

description:
I would recommend not to come here. The older bearded man serving drinks - not a nice man. Buying around for the friends and he goes out of his way to throw profanity my way. Not a good person. 

Theres a lot of other places to go than deal with a rude cigarette dude serving drinks, so I recommend going somewhere else. Use your money Some Where to be appreciate. -love the thick reaper!
author: Lloyd L.

description:
There are a lot of places to drink in the Mission, but not all of them are places that I would regularly return to. Some places are pretentious which is not my thing, and some places are too much of a dive. Don't get me wrong I love a good dive bar but there are a lot of overpriced dumps that don't show me that they value my business. I won't name names but I'm sure you get the idea.

I've had good experiences at Casanova. The place is lively and there are always plenty of attractive ladies, which is a big plus, but not overloaded with hipsters or douchebags. There are comfortable places to sit away from the crowd when you want some one on one time, and plenty of space at the bar when you want to be in the middle of the action.

I'm usually a beer drinker--I love a good IPA-- and I like the fact that they have Racer 5, one of my faves. However, I like to mix things up sometimes with a cocktail recommendation from a good bartender. 

The last time I visited, I asked the bartender to recommend me a good cocktail that wasn't sweet. Ted made me a greyhound with freshly squeezed grapefruit juice and it was delicious. In fact I think I found a new favorite cocktail. I had only had them made with canned juice in the past and it really isn't the same at all. I can say that I will be back for more!

They take cards which is great for me because I always run out of cash. Good vibes, good drinks, and good people. Casanova is definitely in my regular rotation now.
author: Sal O.

description: Super cute, chill and cool crowd. Much better then being in downtown and paying 2x more for a drink.
author: Stacy M.

description: OMG their greyhounds (fresh squeezed grapefruit and vodka).  OMG.
author: Pam L.

description:
Oh, Casanova. We've had many a lovely night on your couches and with your crazy clientele.

They greyhounds are something to write home about and I dig the beers they have on tap.

But really, it's the people that frequent this joint. I've shared a couch with someone that had completely passed out and had to be booted by the bouncer. I've sipped on my greyhound while a puppy tore around the bar collecting pets from patrons like it was going out of style. I've seen dates and reunions and friend catch-up sessions. 

Sit all the way in the back in the chairs that are on a little elevated platform and feel like kings and queens. I dare you. 

The good: the above.
The bad: can get crowded (which also happens to be a hallmark of a good bar).
Bonus: check out the art on the wall. Hope you like nudes.
author: Amanda B.

description: Don't go on a Wednesday night- bartender sucks!!! Super rude. I have 2 stars because the ambiance is great. But, this man is highly offensive.  Maybe he is tired.
author: Irma P.

description: Bartenders are disrespectful and super know-it-all guys. Not suggested at all, tons of bars& clubs arund
author: Arda S.

description: Beware of the long bearded kinky barmen. He is extremely rude. And also high probably. We thought the olives were offer from the house, the moment we touched them he started to SWEAR. Never coming again.
author: Emre Ş.

description: My all time fave bar in the Mission! Mikey and his team are the BEST! The crowd is super chill, the vibe is great, and they even squeeze fresh citrus juices for the drinks. LOVE!
author: Sassy G.

description:
I'm more of a fan for the dive-bar-iness of this place than the drinks themselves. This dark, cash-only, bar is located on Valencia between 16th and 17th in the heart of the mission. The decor is a combination of velvet paintings and comfy sofas...and makes for a relaxing environment amid the high energy of the rest of the mission.

Tip: If you get hungry, Arinell pizza is half a block toward 16th and serves up pizza by the slice.
author: Aaron M.

description:
Love this dive, probably one of my go-to's in the mish.  Super laid back, zero pretense, dirty in a good way (have to step in to know whattaimean), and lots of other options for food/drink/music, all within blocks.  

The drinks are in bucket glasses and the prices are not too SF-y, for which both makes me gasp with excitement.  Love the dark corners and pockets of loungey/sofa space and for the most part the music is on point.  Not so much a main hangout but great to pregame here or night cap it.  

The bathrooms are pretty sketch, so I always just hope that I don't have to get too involved with them, so far so good.  Other than that, straight up my type of dive.
author: D.wight L.

description:
Casanova is a fitting name for this place, as it seduces you slowly, methodically, carefully... it's also a little sleazy, but dive bars are definitely some of my favorite haunts.

This place opens super early (at 4pm) which coincides perfectly with my schedule, since I am off of work by 3:30 at the latest. Happy Hour prices seem reasonable, but  not as cheap as some other Mission spots. My friend Miguel and I always go for the Dark 'n Stormy ($7). Two of these stiff drinks gets me plenty plastered, and then we go and grab a burrito someplace else. A perfect Friday eve!

Staff is very accommodating and friendly. The people inside have all been pleasant, save for one bad experience with a very brash, loud man. Long story short, he was berating me and my friend and basically yelling at us for being young and not as cool as his generation. Other than that one fella, everyone here is super laid back. Patrons chit-chat with their friends and rarely bother the other guests. 

Oh, and there are extremely cute dogs that chill in here (Buddy was a darling!). They perch atop bar stools like the little fuzzy angels that they are.
author: Brandi W.

description:
(  .  Y  .  ) everywhere.

$5 Jameson shots during HH, I'm in.

very loud inside yet everyone is relaxed.

dog friendly.
author: Susy C.

description:
This is the only bar I remember coming to after leaving Etcetera. My friend was getting me a mojito but they didn't have mint. I told him to ask for a malibu and pineapple instead then but somehow I ended up with some fizzy lemonade cocktail that tasted like ass. Still drank it though. A girls gotta do what a girls gotta do. 

Ambiance is nice. Lots of tables and booths. Decent crowd for a Thursday night. Some guy told me I smelled so good he wanted to hang me by my feet in his house to use as a room freshener. 

I've completely forgotten the bar we went to afterwards but the bartender only charged me $10 for three drinks but then later refused to serve me claiming I was slurring my words and I was all WTF NO THATS JUST HOW I TALK.
author: Tiffany V.

description: There's something special about Casanova on a busy night. There are no special bells and whistles, no arcade games, just a unique throwback cocktail vibe. I love the music, the big moroccan lights, the sexy velvet portraits on the wall, and of course the drinks. If they ever do away with the Greyhound special I'll be a much sadder San Franciscan.
author: Jenny M.

description:
A note of warning: do not order any mixed drinks off the menu. It will be gross.

That being said, I like Cassanova. Decent beer selection, stiff cocktails, sinister ambiance, hipsters everywhere. Reminds me of the magic club from "Desperately Seeking Susan", minus the shitty tricks.
author: Abby S.

description:
There is definitely a groovy kind of good vibe in this dark, slightly dank place, and frankly this may be the only bar on the block targeted to my demographic - aging baby boomer on the cusp of Gen-W with memories of lounge lizards drinking daiquiris with lonely housewives looking to be appreciated before the dawn of feminism. Ah yes, with the grape cluster light fixtures and the naked ladies on velvet, this feels like home to me. 

I think I spent most of my time there trying to decide if the lounging nymphet in the painting in the back was Pamela Tiffin, Sharon Tate, or Jane Fonda in "Barbarella". The DJ the afternoon Jamie W. and I were there was rad. He played a record of a Mexican mariachi band playing a particularly toe-tapping version of "The Age of Aquarius/Let the Sunshine In", while they were showing "Harold and Maude" on the wall. 

We didn't sit on one of the several naugahyde couches in the back, but they did look inviting in a hallucinogenic orgy kind of a way. The drinks are a buck off during happy hour, so if you're in a particularly psychedelic mood in a hazy shade of winter, I say check out Casanova for the good-time ambiance. Peace out, man. 

DRINKS - 3.5 stars...tall ones in highball glasses 
AMBIANCE - 4 stars...is that Jim Morrison, man? Far out... 
SERVICE - 4 stars...the bartender rocked, man 
TOTAL - 4 stars...where are my love beads?
author: Ed U.

description: The place and the staff are very down to earth. Great music and drinks. Everyone around me was pretty chatty which made things more fun. Felt like a hipster Cheers.
author: Tiffany R.

description: Cool atmosphere and all in all pretty cozy. The bartender I met first was Peppy (I think that's her name and I apologize if I botched it) and she was the sweetest thing. Even asked what music I liked and played a few tunes for me and my work group. She was funny and just a hoot to be around. Even fed us all pizza! Been back a few times and have run in to her a few of those times which I was happy about. Its very warm lit, comfortable velvet couches, and just really inviting. Everyone seems pretty friendly there and I try and go back whenever working in sf.
author: Rebecca R.

description:
Casanova is not a bar you start at. It's your 3-4th bar after you've hit up your favorites and you're looking for another place to get wasted at for a cheap price. It's a little odd, kind of dark, and their drinks are so-so... but hey, the price is right!

Apparently they take card now, which is nice. I remember when they took cash only... back in the day...

I've only been here when I've been totally plastered. They've got a good amount of space in the back which is nice! And check out those paintings, very risque.
author: Jade R.

description: Unpretentious. Good drinks. Non-corporate. Keeps the original soul of Valencia Street.
author: lance l.

description: Cute place off Valencia and 16th, I love all the mismatched furniture, grape lamps, and random velvet paintings in this bar. My friends and I got the last table in the back which was a nice place to chat and catch up. They have a decent beer selection and the cocktails are also alright with just the right amount of alcohol. Super chill vibe, cheap drinks (especially since SF prices on everything is skyrocketing these days), and nice friendly bartenders.
author: Elaine N.

description:
Been here a couple times and have never had any issues with the service, patrons, or drinks. The $6 margarita comes in a pint glass and will get. you. drunk. As in "I'm only going out for 2 drinks but will be waking up wearing all of the clothes I went out in" drunk. I wish I were kidding. Make sure to grab a burrito before you hit the tequila. Pyramid on tap w/ an orange slice = :) 

Awesome, artful velvet paintings of breasts, breasts, and more breasts. Low lighting (a flattering red glow) and decor of this place is great. Comfy couches, plentiful seating and clean bathrooms seal the deal. Definitely a lounge in every sense of the word - take the raging bro-fest outside.
author: Laura B.

description:
TIP:  good place to chill with friends, can get crowded and loud on weekends.

Has north shore scrimshaw which is great.  look for specials.
author: Jacky K C.

description: We stopped in to check out the decor and have one drink... we had a really tough time getting that one drink and watched the bartender pass us up time after time even though the bar was empty enough that we got seats at the bar immediately. I don't know what the deal was, but after four pass-by/ignores, we left.
author: Greg F.

description: Decent bar. It popped up when I searched for good for dancing and it definitely was not. The music was good but no dance space.
author: Nicola F.

description: Sweet divey spot in the Mission.  I don't go there often because it's a bit out of my way but when I find myself in the area it's definitely a go to spot for some casual drinks.
author: Kirsten M.

description: Love the naked ladies.. Is that odd?!
author: Jaylena P.

description:
Let me preface this by saying that I came on Halloween, so the bar was pretty hectic. However, it was not so crowded that you couldn't get a spot at the bar to order, if it weren't for the pretentious bartenders. 

My boyfriend had started a tab at the bar at 9:30 PM, and at 10 PM, I decided to get another drink. 20 minutes of standing at the bar and trying to catch the bartender's eyes resulted in nothing (the bartenders always seemed to be busy stacking glasses when I tried to catch their eyes, and when I turned to another bartender, they would magically be serving someone else who had just arrived at the bar). After joking with another girl about this problem, I asked my boyfriend to take my spot and try ordering a drink. He was told repeatedly to wait his turn while the bartenders served others who just arrived at the bar. We spent a good chunk of our night 1) trying to order drinks 2) trying to close the tab. 

The drinks weren't too expensive, if you could manage to order them ($6-8 for a cocktail). Next time, I'll pay cash so that I don't have to wait ridiculous amounts of time to close out my tab. Unless I'm dragged here by friends though, there won't be a next time.
author: Sherry Z.

description: Really?  12/11/15 walked in and waited for the bartender (has a beard with a baseball cap)  to serve us and he attends to the women first even if they walked in after us guys!!  WTF?  I have been come here for years and this is the last of it. I'm done with this bar!!!  Taking our $$$ else wear after all these years.  There are many bars that will take our patronage.
author: Jay S.

description: Nice service and mellow atmosphere on a weeknight. Not sure what the weekend would bring. The bar tender had good recommendations and everyone was chill.  I couldn't quite identify the smell but similar to some others in SFO I guess.
author: Gabrielle M.

description: Just a quiet cocktail bar, not really a bar "scene". Few places to sit if you don't have a table, no music/dancing. Maybe best for a quiet Wednesday or Thursday?
author: Zara S.

description:
I'm not sure what exactly I feel about this place so I'll give it 3 stars. 

I kind of wanna say there's nothing much to it, that it's just a divey bar in the Mission that serves cheap drinks, but I feel like there should be more to it, but really there's not (if that makes any sense). There's actually quite a bit of space, and seating which is nice. It can get crowded around the bar, but you can still get a drink fast enough. There's paintings of naked ladies on the wall. Yeah, that's all I got. If you're in the Mission and want a few drinks Casanova's not a bad option.
author: George A.

description:
Oh yeah.

This place has a fun and sultry ambiance at the same time. It's like a West Coast version of Sin City in Philly without the food. A suberb place to kick back and catch up . Fun fact, my profile pic was taken here.
author: Adrienne A.

description:
Titties!  All around the bar there are velvet paintings with titties!  There are also cool vintage lamps, drinks at a good price, and a good music selection.

Did I mention titties?!
author: Thai D.

description: There's honestly nothing better than a stiff mixed drink after a long day at work.  This place is dog friendly! My roommate has a dog, and a good friend mine also has a dog, so coming here with the whole gang has become a tradition. It's VERY dark in there, though, even during the middle of the day. My best experiences have been going at night. Daytime crew isn't as friendly.
author: Alex G.

description: Most authentic crowd north of 17th street in the Mission. It's a roomie bar with great staff and great music. If you wanna escape the weekend crowd without walking too far south, then this is the bar.
author: Jeremy S.

description:
not crowded even during game day.

drinks were either flat or slightly watered down.
i guess thats what happens when you get something on tap and its $4.
author: Jason C.

description: Love this place! Great bartenders and service. It gets crowded on the weekends but there's usually a good crowd, so it's a great place to meet people. The manager Mikey (tall bearded guy) is an awesome guy with lots of interesting stories. Great happy hour deals. They do accept credit cards now and there's an ATM there. The decor is fun- vintage black velvet paintings and pleasant unique intimate lighting. Plenty of seating and good music. There's a big TV usually playing sports, great place to watch the Giants games. Overall, a chill vibe and definitely my favorite SF bar!
author: M J.

description: Cool looking bar, nice bartender, bathrooms are a bit rough but all in all it is a good spot.  One of our many spots of the night and I certainly have nothing to complain about.
author: Bryanna P.

description: I couldn't really put my finger on this place, is it a dive bar, a lounge, a upscale wanna be bar? Also what bar only takes cash they were packed so they must make a decent profit. The drinks are reasonably priced but maybe it's the atmosphere that just didn't vibe with me. In any case if you are on van ness bar hopping I would at least check the place out.
author: Matthew M.

description: This place is a dive and I liked it.  Dimly lit with stiff drinks.  Normally the dive bars on the east coast have shady characters in them but I didn't see any here.  I had a few libations and moved on to the next bar.
author: Zach V.

description:
I waited quite a while to write this review.  My apologies if i go all over the place.

My friends and I started the night off at another venue, but after a subpar experience there, we moved to the Casanova.  My time at Casanova was pretty damn good.  Granted, it became incredibly heated towards the end of it, but the way Mike--i believe the owner?  manager?  someone in charge--resolved my problem, was amazing.  He's a damn good guy.

As other people have stated, the bathroom is no joke hilarious.  Tons of writing over the wall, and my experience was made even weirder by two guys in the stall yelling to each other in spanish.  I didn't start peeing because they were yelling obscenities and, to be honest, the whole thing was pretty hilarious.  And when i was about to start peeing...they started yelling at me--in spanish, mind you--to zip up my pants and to walk away.  Of course, their statements were... graphic. Suffice it to say, i didn't really listen to them.

Afterwards, the drink i ordered--a red bull/sprite...i don't drink--was decently mixed.  My friends liked their drinks for the most part.  I don't think i can really make any other comments with regard to drinks.

Ambiance though?  Definitely.

Casanova was fairly dive-y, but i really enjoyed the lighting and the burgundy/maroon/brown and reddish tones in the bar.  The paintings on the wall were distracting...but obviously in a good way haha.  My friends and I moved to the back of the bar and sat down on the big, incredibly comfortable, red couch.

This couch deserves it's own paragraph because it is just SO badass.  It's amazingly comfortable and it is quite big.  I remember sitting down and sinking into the couch--not too much, and not little...the perfect amount.  After immediately sitting down, we all noticed how bouncy it was.  OMG is it bouncy.  I think I was bouncing and dancing to music the entire time we were there (3+ hours maybe?).  My friends and I had numerous conversations about how amazing it is and we started hatching an Ocean's 11 type plan to steal it.  Man, I love that couch.

The music was awesome too.  There were a whole bunch of classic rock, oldies, and other tunes that one could really dance/groove to.  I reallllly enjoyed the music and I wish i had a track listing of everything played that night.

The only problem i had though was when i misplaced my hat--i believe behind the couch in the back?--and i couldn't find it when it came time to closing.  The hat was ~$70, but it has an incredible amount of sentimental value to me.  Suffice it to say, things got heated when i asked for more time to search for my hat or if i could just wait inside as they cleaned up/closed, but i wouldn't really let the whole hat thing go.  And when my friends and the staff started talking about how someone could have stolen the hat, i started to lose my cool.

Anyway, i waited outside of the bar for about 30 minutes with my friends, and my homie Mike came outside after he found my hat.  Man, i was so upset and frustrated at the thought of losing my hat/getting it stolen, but Mike took the time to look for my hat after I made things very difficult for him.  He knew how important the hat was for me and--maybe this is one of the reasons why he went out of his way to help me?--we exchanged a few words about Spider-Man.

Next time in SF, i hope to visit this bar and say what's up to Mike.  Definitely recommend this place for anyone looking for a chill night with friends and fun music.
author: Fai Z.

description:
The bar itself has a cool themed decor. As others have mentioned, it's got strange framed naked girl 'art' (that term being very loosely used) all around the walls and is very dimly lit.

But the type of crowd that comes here on a Friday or Saturday night leaves something to be desired. It gets full of your typical mission weekender, which I find very annoying to be around. But i guess this is probably the case for most bars in the mission on the weekend.

Beer's reasonably priced ($4 for anchor, my go-to), though it sucks that it's cash only. Can't vouch for the mixed drinks but the bartenders know what they're doing so i'm sure they're alright.

The best thing you can do here is check out Phonogram on the third Friday of every month. While you might be surrounded by mostly lame people, you'll at least be able to hear DJ Major Sean and Ronnie spin great tunes all night.
author: Jon T.

description:
There is an allure to this page that I don't quite understand. Maybe its the artsy magical lanterns adorning the bar or perhaps the paintings of naked (and tasteful) bodies that adorn walls or the dim lighting or the multitude of seating arrangements including bar, couches and high top tables.

I say this because they still manage to get a 3 star rating and I know that I will probable go back again in spite of their "Tastes like Gatorade" margaritas (and I don't like Gatorade) and their music which is constantly too loud to allow the Casanova Lounge to serve the purpose it should be perfect for; libation + conversation
author: Mo A.

description: Meh, I've experienced better. See initial statement.  Meh!!!!!!!!!!!
author: Michael D.

description: What a fun place.  We were looking for a bar while walking around San Francisco and peeked in.  Since we had our dog with us and there were several there, we went in.  Fun staff and regulars, and great pizza two doors down that you can bring in.
author: Shags S.

description: This place is not accepting of Identification from other countries. They were not willing to be understandable about an identification card from France and accused my boyfriend of forfeiting his ID. I highly do not recommend coming here, their service is not great either. The experience was condescending and extremely uncomfortable. This was my one and only experience here, and I never plan to ever come here again. I suggest you do the same.
author: Jenn S.

description: Casanova is quickly becoming my local watering hole. Everyone has their "bar type" and this is definitely mine. You can pop in anytime and there will be a seat for you and good beer on tap. Leather lounge couches and velvet paintings of beautiful nudes tie it all together. Last, but certainly not least is the service. I've had consistently pleasant bartenders across the board on countless occasions - specifically Shelley. If you decide to pop in for a beverage go, out of your way to order from her. She certainly went out of her way to help me and the obnoxiously loud and large group that I came in with. Keep up the good work, folks.
author: Rick S.

description: dingy valencia bar...very dog friendly...aged with old class...standard wooden bar long...vinyl booths and drapes...surrounded by nude paintings all around...happy hour four pm to seven pm...$dollar off all drinks...$five pbr and jameson shots...$six margarita pints...guinness for $four and $dollar tip for pour...sip and waiting along the bar...few people seated at the bar after work hours...friendly drink and chat...friends arriving and orders all around...dark and stormy?...tanqueray and tonic?...self taking the $five pbr and jameson shots...three drinks roughly $sixteen and $three tip...migrating to the red vinyl booths...a second round and off next door to gajalee...
author: Hen A.

description:
My favorite Mission bar for so many reasons:

- The bartenders.. okay, make that a bartender.  I go here because Margarita is an amazing bartender who shows passion for her work and actually makes some of the best margaritas I've ever had in my life.  The other bartenders will get you a drink, but they're clearly not into their jobs and the quality shows.
- These guys pour heavy.  If you're into powerful beverages and into bars where they don't measure the exact amount of alcohol that goes into each drink, then you'll love it here.
- The prices are reasonable.
- Great location as it's only a block away from the 16th and Mission Bart.

Negatives?

- Cash only bar.  This is likely great for their accounting, but not convenient for customers.
- Music can be ungodly loud at times.
author: Jan S.

description:
A pint size margarita....only could finish about one third of them.
We sat on the large couch and it was comfortable. Nice bar.
author: Yoko S.

description: not recommended, bouncer and waiters are rude.  They are threatening to give us bad review for not tipping enough. WTF!
author: Hubert P.

description: A divey bar without any frills at all. Seriously, the bathroom is tagged beyond belief, and the walls are adorned with paintings of naked women. You can chill in one of the booths with a fairly decent beer, or there are stools and tables if that's more your liking. If you're feeling super fancy, there's a giant couch in the back. Based on what I saw on Wednesday night, you're on your own if you want to brave the couch. This place is just funky in all senses. I swear, my last beer tasted like the smell of an old, used sock.
author: Danny C.

description: My group of friends and myself were verbally attacked by an off the clock bartender named Peppers who was obviously drunk, and has severe anger issues. Her dog, who was wandering around the bar my himself, tried to eat our food and my friend snapped her fingers at the dog which then backed off. The owner of the dog, stomped over and began to curse and scream at her for snapping her fingers (no one touched the dog, and as a dog trainer I stand behind how my friend handled the dog) and then proceeded to scream at the rest of us as we defended her. She then yelled at us that she worked at Casanova's and left. Then returned again supposedly to apologize but was obviously looking to start a fight. My friend talked to the on the clock bartender who had no response, gave her information to the bar and has been calling for 3 days to speak to the manager or owner of the establishment about how she was treated by their employee and has gotten no response. Not only am I horrified by this employee, but the management's lack of response is disgusting. I and all my friends who have frequented this bar often will never return and advise anyone who doesn't want to be harassed by employees not to go.
author: Sara C.

description: In the midst of the busy Mission bar scene Casanova is a cool, chill bar that is a good place to hang with your friends. It does not have much ambiance decor is  trashy looking red walls with paintings of busty women and mustached men, cheap looking leather couches and red cabaret lights. Rather divey  bar but is intimate enough with couches and tables for people to chat. Drinks are cheap, music is loud.... I always manage to get a seat even if the place is packed. Over-all a good bar to hang out on a weekday or weekend.
author: Maria M.

description:
I love the Casanova Lounge. It's the coolest. I love the paintings, I love the atmosphere, I love the patrons, I love the staff, but most of all I love.... Ted.
Ted is the awesomest door guy/bartender ever. He's super good looking, his hair is flawless he's super stylish and has the perfect hight to weight ratio (I don't care what Tim says), he is also an amazing bartender. Ted knows his shit. He's fast, always charming and clever and his drinks taste like sex. 
Ted is the best. thing. ever.
author: Ted S.

description:
Since writing my original review, I've received several replies (here and e-mail) from Casanova associates saying "Sorry, but it's the law" and "That's California."

So here's the deal. A good bar IDs at the door. It's how many of the bars do it in California and how all bars do it in more conservative states. We're adults. We understand the need to ID. That's not the issue. The issue is that a group of 30-year-olds were treated like criminals trying to buy alcohol for kids when only two of us wanted a drink. The entire party was made to parade up to the bar from the back where we'd settled in, to show all of our IDs. I cannot repeat this enough - so only two of us could get beer. And all because the owners of Casanova clearly don't understand that most bars successfully comply to all laws by posting someone at the door. And here's a little secret, those bars that don't ID at the door, either ID the person buying alcohol at the bar (not the whole f-ing party) or just don't ID (which I'm not arguing is correct, though Casanova doesn't seem to understand this).

So, way to miss the point, Casanova. I won't be returning.
author: Elisha A.

description:
Divey, hipster, and dark.  Super comfortable couches.  Okay service, okay price.

Not a bad choice for an afternoon drinking session with friends.  

Make sure to check out the velvet paitings, they're ridiculously fantastic.
author: Margaret I.

description:
Yup! Everything right and wrong about the Mission. You feel uneasy as you run the cray-cray gauntlet up 16th or Valencia, but once inside you find a tall glass of PBR, a velvet painting of Bruce Lee and some tunes blasting that everyone agrees are way better than anything on the radio. Can I get a hipster hallelujah! 

For reals though, a downright cool place to get your drink on. It's dimly lit with wide open areas to mingle or slowly sway to a gritty telecaster groove with friendly bar staff that don't judge you even though you're not a regular of the neighborhood. Definitely a place on my list to come back and was glad to have stumbled across it.
author: Tony C.

description:
They play Michael McDonald.  You gotta love a place that bumps 'what a fool believes.'

Crowd is pretty chill (and it's NOT all hipster, some of these reviews are way off)  Drinks are pretty stiff. And pretty cheap.

Naked women 'art' paired with the dim lighting of several eclectic light fixtures...  it makes for an interesting place to hang out.   My friend was smitten and wishing Buffalo NY had something remotely close to Casanova.

What's not to love here?  If you are a huge fan of Bubble Lounge or other places with uppity folk that rob you with $14martinis and $16 gimlets, this place shouldn't be on your list.  Ever.
author: Athena S.

description:
Nice place to duck into between drinking, shopping and dinner bouts.  The 'tender was very good on making sure she knew you were waiting to order on a busy night.

But what's with the fruit hanging from the ceiling?
author: Lorrayne L.

description: Met a friend here for drinks last night. I'd say it's a typical dive bar. Super dark, chill bartenders, good drink prices, no real complaints. Oh, they take card ($10 minimum charge), which is always a plus for this cash-free girl.
author: Candace R.

description:
Wow.  I had fun at a hipster bar?  Really?  It's true.  I really dig this place and, if I lived in SF, I would come here a lot.  The music is awesome.  It's like Dusty Springfield told her bff's to dj her house party after all the squares left.  Every track made me feel as though I was in an early-era Tarantino movie.  The low red lights/paint added to my experience.  Rather than making me feel I should be looking out for backwards-speaking dwarfs, I felt like I was in the mood for a good dose of cool.  

It is a divey bar, so there are some precautions you should take.  1.) drink your alcohol out of bottles.  I don't care what kind of drink specials you offer, I am a crazy-@ss germaphobe.  I'm not trusting my lips to your glass washing.  It's nothing personal.  Bottle choices: cider and Pacifico.  I drank Pacifico.  If I were more secure in my manhood, I would have had the cider.  2.) Pictures of boobies on the wall.  It's art, not porn.  3.) The bathroom was a bit of a nightmare.  I'd suggest going when you REALLY have to go and not any time before.  

That said, I had a great evening here with one of my best, oldest friends and a new, Hawaiian mama jama amiga.  We had great conversations, childish giggles, plastic couches and good drinks/cheers all around.  No matter how old you get, spending a night drinking good brew and talking with good people will make you feel as though everything you're doing right then, right now...is right.  I felt 'right' here.  Like my girl Dusty said, "you don't have to say you love me, just be close at hand."  This place is close at hand.  I think you'll like it.
author: Johnny T.

description:
I wish Yelp would add a negative star rating, because that is what this place deserves. I just got a voicemail from the bar manager threatening me with a lawsuit because of my comments on this "establishment". This bar is an even bigger joke than I ever thought it was. I had spent thousands at this place over the years I've lived in this city and for them to turn face and treat someone whom WAS a loyal regular customer, over a complete misunderstanding with an incompetent bartender is complete bullshit. If you're gonna waste your money drinking I strongly suggest you do it at one of the dozens of other bars it this neighborhood.
 It use to be a decent place, but that was years ago.
author: Brian M.

description: Laid back crowd , good drinks, nice vibe. Love the  fire place in the middle. Fast service, different crowds each night. You don't know who will run into??
author: Claudine V.

description: Great spot for day time drinking. The bartender are very friendly and pour great drinks. You don't typically want to come here on the weekends except maybe Sunday afternoon, maybe? Well actually I'm here now and it's Sunday at 6 so I guess I can say that you should come here around this time on Sundays to miss the rush and it's a dollar off drinks. Sounds like a good time, right?
author: Ayele A.

description: Great, cozy, interesting neighborhood bar.  Lots of lovely art on the walls, especially if you love breasts, and super comfy booths to sit in.  The place seemed pretty packed when we were there but it didn't feel that way, which was nice.  It's definitely a fun bar to go to when you're in the area.
author: Allison R.

description: Wow. Way to treat a local. Thurs night ain't the time to go. Grumpy Bar guy. I actually understand why he might be grumpy but he shouldn't project that on the rest of the world.
author: Lenny K.

description:
Before you even consider checking this bar out, be forewarned that Valencia is hipster central. If that's a problem for you, run back to Walnut Creek. (Sick burn!) However, if that's not a problem and you enjoy $1.50 PBR pints and $6 PBR pitchers at Happy Hour (4-7pm, bitches!), cool and random music coming from the jukebox, and 70s pornish velvet paintings of naked ladies (really, who doesn't?), then the Casanova Lounge is the right place for you. The couches are awesome, the decor is disarming, amusing, and kind of indulgent all at once, and the bartenders are fun, if a little loopy. It's not overtly pretentious, in spite of the street it's on, and, as with so many hipster-infused things and places, if one can shed one's prejudice, it's actually a really awesome, fun, cool bar.

I prefer to get weekday happy hour drinks here, when it's a little hoppin', but I still have a chance of snagging a couch or even a spot in the wikid little "VIP" alcove in the back (I loves to sit under that one naked lady velvet painting, oh yeah). On weekends, it's very crowded and standing room only, and that isn't really what I'm looking for in a place called a "lounge"--or in any bar, for that matter. But the Casanova is still a fun, cool little spot.  

That said, I'm more than happy to brave the inevitable headache from drinking happy hour draft PBR, which, for the price, is worth the immediate regret that you feel in your mouth and brain. $6 pitchers don't make it taste any better, and, in true hipster style, the Casanova is too good for Bud Light, which is clearly superior to PBR (as is everything this side of Natty Ice and Steel Reserve), but proud of their Pabst. Go figure. 

This would be a 5-star place if it weren't for the excessive crowding that almost always occurs, as well as the fact that they've recently painted over all of the really cool graffiti in the bathroom, which has long been one of my favorite features of this bar.
author: Ashley M.

description:
So this is one of these places that I've been to, multiple times, but each time I forget that I've ever been here.

You know how that goes - you're walking with your friends through the mission looking for the next stop and your friend says "have you ever been to Casanova" and you say, with full confidence "no," then you walk in and you feel that awkward feeling coming up and you think "actually...this looks slightly familiar"

Now sure why I always keep forgetting that I've been here, especially since it's usually the beginning of the night that I end up here, not the end of the night.

It's a very dark bar, but I like that they have a very long bar. It's cozy in the back. Bathrooms are dirty.
author: Helen D.

description:
Chill bar with a lounge-like feel. Kinda weird vibe at times, but a good end-up spot. 

*Cash only
*Bathrooms in back
*Seating
*Dark
*$5 beers
*ATM machine
author: Shira O.

description:
I was nearby with some friends and looking for a spot to grab a glass of champagne when I found this place. Although not a champagne bar, we were able to buy a few minis of Moet here which hit the spot. When we first arrived it was crowded with a big group, but they left not too long after we arrived (I'd like to think we drove them out) which made the ambiance a little better. After they left, the remaining amount of people left was just right. Definitely your typical Mission crowd, but I was okay with that (good people watching.) 
After the Moet, we had a few beers and I personally sampled the Moscow Mule. I have had a few of these in my day, and I liked the version here very much. Some Moscow Mules will kick you in the face with the ginger and then in the back with lime, but I found the one here only really kicks you in the face, and that's how I like it. Although not served in the traditional copper mug, (read: smaller size), I still thought it was a decent deal at 6$. The other beers were enjoyed and there seemed to be something for everyone.
Music was also pretty good. A solid choice for a few drinks.
author: Rachel B.

description: Idk about this place the vibe seems blah..I'm all about checking out the dive bars on vacation but i somehow feel this place isn't really a dive bar..drinks are about 3 bucks more than the other bars which is strange but whatever..the doorguy is fun atleast..on to the next location..
author: Chandler P.

description: This bar reminds me of the ShadyLady bar in Sacramento because of the paintings inside.  It's nice that there is no cover but the crowd is not as big as blondie's across the street.  Bartenders are nice.
author: Jennifer S.

description: Terrible service on New Years! I will never go back, the bartenders were all rude on New Year's Eve. Really? They lost my friends CC and blamed it on him. They threatened to kick him out and when they finally found his card on the floor they still charged him for a drink he never signed for... Shady bar if you ask me. The atmosphere was very relax but the bar wasn't that crowded probably because of the rude bartenders.
author: Jack D.

description: Saturday night but not terribly crowded. Lots of comfortable seating. Nice place to sit and talk to your friends with elevated voices.
author: Gee H.

description:
What can I say about Casanova Lounge....

Well, it has a cool Mission-y atmosphere. I like the lights hanging from the ceilings, and the comfy seat in the back by the bathrooms. I like that fact that there is hardly ever a line (at least I've never seen one), so when everywhere else is at capacity Casanova is an obvious go-to place. I like that it is right next to my favorite mexican place, because what's better than scarfing down a cheap taco or quesadilla after a night of bar hopping? I like that there are so many hot guys, even though they are ALL super shy and would never approach a girl. Mission hipsters..geez! 
However, I dislike the fact that it's always super packed and hard to move. I also have never really enjoyed myself here. Actually I've felt kind of bored being here. I'm not sure why, because I've gone w/ super cool people. I guess it's just not for me!
author: Sonya D.

description: Love the purty lamps, the ambiance and cheap drinks! Cool crowd and great winning Giants game!
author: Karen T.

description: I have no string feeling about this place. It wasn't great and it wasn't bad. There were some couches in the back which I liked and the bouncers were really nice. The meadow Moscow mule was weird they added a bitter on top which ruined the taste for me. Music was pretty good
author: Miriam G.

description: We went in after Limon across the street. We were having a great night until we got kicked out aggressively. The reason? My friend waited for a while to grab the managers attention to have a beer. When he got the attention, got the worst most rude service. And he wrote on the receipt: I didn't like you.... The reaction: the manager went outside the bar, grabbed my friend, threw his beer and kicked him out like he was punching other people. Went to talk to him reasonably and he started freaking out, swearing, thinking he's the king of the world. With all calm we left... Great other bars around. No time for that hipster prick.
author: Raimundo O.

description: Ended up here after having crappy service at La Rondalla. We were looking for some drinks while passing through the city. I heard Rondalla had the best Margaritas, yet we never got to have any because the service was non-existent. we walked out after being ignored. Walked A few blocks and found Casanova. Great atmosphere, very comfortable. Loved the decor, especially the grape lamps, good music, and most importantly AWESOME drinks! Not overly priced like some places either. so it TOTALLY hit the spot. Will definitely come through here again next time in the area!! :)
author: Margarita S.

description:
I have a hangover that leads me to believe I either had a badass time last night at Casanova OR I got punched in the face repeatedly. I don't recall offending anyone to the point of a fist fight so I'm going to assume it was just an awesome night. I think.

Full bar, decent music, lots of pretty ladies. If you ask for more than that in a bar you're just being picky.
author: Justin N.

description:
Casanova was actually one of the major stops back in my bar hopping days.  But I don't know, in the past decade this place (and the mission) has become saturated in "hipster" galore, probably a splitting image of Wiliamsburg.

The bartenders make the drinks alright; when it's a packed night, you'll find them heavy handed =)

Then when you're shmammered there's pizza next door.
author: Edrian D.

description:
Extremely disappointed by staff. Cousin's birthday, and other cousin went to order us drinks, but bartender misunderstood regular vodka soda with vodka tonic, which I am allergic. When asked by bartender to replace w/ a v/s was told to "fuck my cousin" and not to ask such silly questions by manager. 

Needless to say, not going back anytime soon!
author: Megan R.

description:
Casanova is high on my list of "places to go to get really messed up". This is a good thing.

Every drink I've had here has been tasty and STRONG. The bartenders seem equally at home pulling pints and shaking martinis or Manhattans or margaritas. Speaking of margaritas, they're strong, come in a pint glass, and still taste like margaritas (as opposed to Latin American Club where they taste like a glass of tequila that was at one time near some lime juice).

I love the decor: nude portraits and the most eclectic collection of lamps and chandeliers in town, against dark red walls.

Bring a bunch of friends, have a bunch of drinks, and then stumble out the door to find some tacos. Lather, rinse, repeat.
author: Sam K.

description: Happy hour is the right time to go here.  Nice ambiance, you can easily find a seat, not too crowded.  Also, the beers are 3 bones until 7 pm I believe.  3. bones. each.  Not many places in SF can offer that.  I've heard it gets crowded here the later it gets but again... happy hour is where it's at.
author: Mel G.

description:
At this point, I was well on my way to being supremely blotto, but persevered.  Why?  Because as I've mentioned (repeatedly), I'm an idiot and feel the need to be as masochistic as possible.  

A "friend" (and at this point, I use that term really loosely, so much that I pretty much hate his guts today.  This will probably change when I get some beauty sleep because I don't hold grudges) told me that he would be here after he had dinner.  As I hadn't seen him in awhile, and never when he's not working, I said okay, I'll go.  

Although they probably hate me now, I dragged FOUR OTHER PEOPLE with me, saying that "hey, something new to Yelp."  Funny how the word Yelp turns people into sheep.

Although my "friend" never showed up (despite assurances from first him via a telephone call and then later from friends of his), we did manage to do a little exploring.  I managed to explore the men's restroom because I got a little lost.  This seems to happen a lot, or maybe I just like to check out the goods before I buy.   The drinks were reasonably priced, there were pictures of naked chicks on the wall, there were lights strewn above, there were glass grape sculpture things hanging, and eventually there was a couch for us to sit on.  

I don't go to the Mission often, but it's not a bad place.  Not my favorite, but not the worst either.

Which is more than I can say for my "friend."  

Jerk.

**********Update*********

So the little button to "write an update" isn't down there yet, and before I forget, I wanted to give everyone anxiously awaiting on the edge of their seats what could have happened to my "friend."  Thankfully, I am a patient person, and pretty tolerant of a lot of things that happen in life.  I'm also kind of a bitch in other ways and will cut you out of my will if you hurt me (although all you would get is 2 cats and a supremely dented car).  

I have been a bartender for a long time, and continue to be when I need the extra cash.  I have been in some crazy situations over the years because of it (if you want to hear about them sometime, I'd be happy to oblige).  Apparently my "friend" got caught up with some of his cronies, and lost track of all space and time.  He did offer to take me to dinner, but as that could be McDonalds, I still consider him to be in the "jerk" category.  

Which is frankly filling up kind of fast as of late.
author: Pam S.

description: Great happy hour with a relaxed, dive atmosphere. Booths, bar, and tables. And a little Pomeranian mascot. Great dive joint.
author: Caitlin R.

description: What a terrible place. No service. This place could make so much money. The staff must hate the owners. Hopefully they have a lot  of money because profit must not be a big deal. Feel free to respond. Bar rescue needed here.
author: Ryan S.

description: Y'know, maybe I'm just too old for this scene. But in SF, *especially* in the mission, there really isn't a good excuse for having a bar without a solid whiskey collection. If you're in the mood for an endearingly kitschy dive bar and cheap drinks? Sure. Why not. But otherwise? There are plenty of other places to go nearby.
author: Brett W.

description:
Yet another "sheer luck" find. I stumbled out of a cab, finishing my phone call and following my friends into Casanova's.

I hung up the phone and looked around. Velvet paintings featuring topless women (the only kind of velvet painting that should exist, in my opinion), a packed crowd of youngsters set to party mode and Misfits playing.

I incredulously asked my girlfriend how we ended up here, to which she replied "I started picking bars by examining the crowd out front."  Well, done dear girl!

The music and crowd was rockin' and we lucked out by scoring a table in the back. Bartenders were quick with shot and beer orders and no complaints: homey, energetic and good music=three thumbs up from me.
author: Lauren V.

description:
If you were to judge this bar by its cover, you'd probably think: cheap drinks, nothing of memorable quality and a dark and standard spot to nourish your inner lush. But when I saw a chalk board outside promoting hibiscus margaritas, I thought this place might be awesome. 

The appropriately named bartender, Margarita, sauntered over to us with her pink neckerchief trailing behind her. A true expert of her craft, she assured us the hibiscus margs were the way to go. She prided herself on concocting the best drinks and particularly of note was the meticulousness she employed with every cocktail made. A bloody mary wasn't complete without adding individual spices, a teaspoon of horseradish, and a splash of Guinness; a margarita wasn't up to par without similarly fresh ingredients. And while all the other SF cocktologists marry their speakeasy flair to create a ménage of flavors in a glass, Margarita was swift and unpretentious in her execution, always putting flavor and freshness first. 

The nude women in the frames on the wall stared at me and while I sipped on my hibiscus pleasure and noshed on my Arinell NY style slice, I realized this was the best $6 I'd spent all day.
author: Monica S.

description:
Favorite dive bar in the hood...  interesting mixed Mission/hipster/"San Francisco" crowd during the week -- overpopulated with Marina/B&T types on the weekends (like the rest of the Mission I suppose).

Also a convenient place to wait (forever) for your table to be ready across the street at Puerto Alegre.

Fancy Mexican velvet paintings on the walls add some flair.
author: Kevin F.

description:
Each time I come here, I end up spending a grand total of five minutes or so before moving on. That's certainly no testament to the place itself, seeing as I really like the vibe I've gotten, regardless of my experiences in small doses.  The lighting is nice and Skott (also of Hemlock fame) is kind of a babe.

But something about this places seems chill, and not overly ridiculous. And if it weren't for friends beckoning me to meet up with them elsewhere within minutes of stepping through the doors, I'd stick around a bit longer. In fact, next time I'm in town, Casanova will definitely be a destination for me.
author: Natalye R.

description:
I like this bar because:

necked women pictures
non existant lighting
strong drinks, and
EVERYBODY looks good in this bar.
author: Gina B.

description:
BOOBIES EVERYWHEREEEEEEEE!!!!!!! We hopped here after finding out SOM Bar would be open at 10pm rather than 9pm. It looked crowded, but it actually wasn't bad. After getting our drinks at the bar without having to wait too long, we stood around chatting. 20 minutes later, a table left and we got to sit at the end of the place on the comfy couches. It's located right in between the 2 bathrooms, so we got to see the entire lounge from our spot.

It wasn't super loud, so it was easy to sit around and chat. Our drinks were pretty strong. Needless to say, we'll be coming back. Plus the bartenders are quick to serve here, which I always like.
author: Stephanie Y.

description:
It's dark in this place. There are lots of velvety paintings of topless women with 70's style haircuts. 

The best thing about this place is its location - lots of other cool bars and restaurants nearby. 

Did I mention velvet boobie paintings? Just thought you should know.
author: Nate R.

description:
The couch in the back is empty.  We are lucky.  The place is mostly empty, twenty people max, maybe.  I am drinking a Jack and Coke.  She is drinking a White Russian.  The booze is cheap.  She is loosening up, telling me about a play she saw a couple of months ago,  the Big Lebowski performed in the style of Shakespeare.  It makes me laugh to hear it.  She laughs, too. 

I watch her as she speaks.  She is not quite beautiful, but close to it.  I am distracted by a velvet portrait of a nude woman.  The music is loud, the Clash.  The vibe is cool, but I struggle to hear her over the music.  

"Those paintings are funny," she says, pointing up to one of the paintings with a nude woman sitting on a large rock.  "Really says something about the taste of the clientele."  Her smile grows wider in her buzz.  And I have a buzz, too. 

"Yeah," I say, suddenly desperate to be clever.  Clever in an edgy way. Clever in a sexy way.   So, this is what I say above the din of the music, now the New York Dolls.  "Yeah," I say, nodding my head, "I wouldn't mind tying her up and down."  

And just like that, I am someone else to her.  

I didn't mean to be creepy. I was just referencing her first words to me, back at Lost Weekend.  But, it doesn't matter.  It is already over.  With those few words, sitting alone with her in the backroom of Casanova, the booze a little too cheap, the music a little too loud,  and yes, me, a little too creepy, I am instantly a stranger to her.   She doesn't finish her white russian.  Five minutes later, she is gone.  And I sit here alone, staring at the ice in my otherwise empty glass.  

The night will be a long one.   At least the music is loud.  At least the booze is cheap.
author: P. William G.

description:
Thursday: 12/72006 
- 9:25p Arrival
- 10:00p Departure

I've been a Mission bars virgin for a very long time.  I was so stoked, last night, a classmate from Junior high school called me up, said he was going to take me bar hopping in the Mission!  

The bar was pretty crowded, but we were lucky to find a table.  Did not have much time to look around, but I did enjoy a Pint of PBR for $2.50.  I wasn't too crazy about the loud music, but I loved the lighting inside.  The crowd seemed clique, but I didn't mind it.  There were a lot of big groups of friends hanging out, then couples having a great time, but there were also guys sitting at tables/couches who were clearly by themselves...  

Would go here again sometime, but would not be my first bar stop when I'm in the Mission :-)!
author: Celeste M.

description:
cheap drinks
velvet paintings of ladies

I LOVE IT!

PS big ass comfy couch to loiter on :)
author: Anne-Mary P.

description: Romantic and decadent. Love the couch area in the back room!
author: Erica D.

description:
After being spurned by a nearby bar due to a technicality, we ended up here on a Saturday night. The doorman couldn't care less about expired driver's licenses. Yay.

Even though it was crowded, we were able to get drinks right quick and met some fun, random people and we all made a big fat party of it all.

Dark, a bit seedy, but nice bartenders who pour a stiff drink.

I won't mention the paintings of naked women bc that's been done to death.
author: Meg W.

description:
Your typical Mission hole in the wall bar.  One thing to note it's cash only but not cheap, my Kettle/soda was $9 which is inline with most other bars in the city.  

If you get here early you can find a seat, the great thing is it's all first come first serve, not the usual trend of if you want to sit you have to buy a bottle that is spreading through the city.  

The crowed is really mixed and casual which is nice compared to the Marina, but then don't assume everyone is interested in the opposite sex here, not the case.  But don't worry guys, there are tons of paintings on the wall depicting women in the nude with great cleavage.
author: Inga W.

description: Love this place! Service is stellar and I love the vibe. Always a great hang out when in the Mission. Service is quick and friendly, the staff there really takes care of you and always makes us feel welcome. Great cocktails and super fun bartenders. I'll be back soon!
author: Ferguson J.

description:
Chill venue. Kicked off one of our nights here. It's pretty spacious, plenty of seating. And the drinks are CHEAP. My jaw dropped when I saw how little they charged compared to the places I've been in Los Angeles, Vegas, and NYC. Very affordable. I think it's a great place to bring a large group and by rounds -- rounds won't get cheaper than this.

And lots of artwork showing exposed breasts. And one random painting of Bruce Lee if memory serves correctly. Chyea Bruce.
author: Ken T.

description: This place is the tits! Literally cause there's pictures of some all over! Bartenders are rad and like to have fun while busting their tails. Music is always rad and adds to the smooth ambiance.... The chick bartenders are hot and sassy and knows just how to make people feel good! Check this place out for sure if you're ever visiting SF!
author: Rose B.

description:
I like this place. I do. Cheap stiff drinks, nice chill venue, and the most random crowd. Yes random. 

In the hour or so I was there last Saturday night, I met the most random people. One after another. A db from L.A who couldn't stop talking about his Maserati, an awkward red haired hipster who I swore was wearing jeggings, a 40 something creep with spiky hair...

And it seemed like there was no one to clear glasses from the bar or tables.  I'm sure there was a DJ that night but for the life of me I can't remember anything about the music. Oh, can't forget to mention that it is DARK in here.  Was packed at around midnight but the crowd soon dissipated after that.
author: Hoa T.

description: Cheap drinks with a really cool loungy vibe is what Casanova is all about. The decor screams "ravish me" while the drinks whisper "stay awhile". Mind you, if you come here on the weekend, forget about getting any kind of beverage in under 20 minutes. The place is hopping with every kind of hipster trying not to be hipster imaginable, which means that  holding a conversation is also a mission impossible. But who cares? The people watching is delightful!
author: Danielle F.

description:
Shots here are big and cheap! 5 bucks for a Jameson neat half full in your glass. Think I saw a beer and shot $5 combo for happy hour too. One of the best deals around! 

Vibe here is so-so.. Very hipster-ish with a dim lit saloon style atmosphere. 

The drinks here are made strong and shots are fat, that's what counts!
author: Patrick L.

description: The manager is the worst guy I have ever dealt with. He thinks he is a hipster cool guy that can do whatever he wants. Hopefully there can be some better management in the future.
author: Felipe J.

description:
Dear Hipster Bartender,

I have money, that I want to give to you, that you can then use to pay for another haircut by a blind man with safety scissors and a new pair of neon jeans but YOU WON'T TAKE IT! 

I hate you.

XOXO,
Jess T.
author: Jess T.

description:
So this place is fun, but be warned it's VERY dark inside. My first time I lost my friends and grabbed some dudes arm thinking it was my boys.
