Whoops. 

Otherwise, no complaints. Supposed humor like art on the wall, but meh, nothing to write home about.
author: Jessica A.

description:
This place is a little schizophrenic, but you can expect that for a bar that's situated on the tourist/hipster hotspot at Valencia and 16th. On weeknights, it's a somewhat low-key place for a beer with friends. But on the weekends, it's glutted with tourists, some locals, and people from other neighborhoods or the East Bay. 

My friend djs here once a month on Fridays, and I'm usually hit on by recent grads who want to know where I went to school, or out-of-towners who are looking for a good time. There's a tiny "dancefloor" by the jukebox and dj booth that is really just populated with people standing around because all the seats are taken. But that's on a Friday night, when it's absolutely packed, when people walking down Valencia will wander in and out.

On the plus side, the drinks are usually pretty cheap, with some great deals on beer on tap. And it's conveniently located, right around the corner from where my friend lives and where I can meet friends coming from nearby neighborhoods.

On the downside: for a dj night, you must know that the speaker system sucks. The sound gets muffled and lost among the din of the crowd that i can almost never identify what song my friend is playing unless I strain to hear it. There's only one stall for the ladies' bathroom, and it ain't pretty. And if you don't like cheesy velvet paintings of naked women all over the walls, you'll feel really uncomfortable here.
author: Robin L.

description: Come here for happy hour regularly. Mission vibe, hipsters, cool furniture and lots of space. Bartenders can be inattentive at times but overall a fun place.
author: James D.

description:
A cheap place to start a drunken night.

Well drinks $5, beer $3.5. 

There is a DJ, music is your usual chill Mission lounge/house mix.

Crowd are mixed, but mostly harmless.

Could be a quick stop for some Mission bar hopping night.
author: Alice C.

description:
This is one of my favorite places to throw back a few drinks after work or early on a weekend evening.

Dark, good stuff on the jukebox, lots of cozy sofas, and cool lighting fixtures.  Oh, the drinks are cheap, too (and strong...they don't skimp on the alcohol).  The guys who go here with me also appreciate the kitschy naked lady paintings on the walls.

I'm sure this place probably becomes lame in the evenings.  However, if you're looking for a relaxed place to have cheap drinks after work before moving onto another bar or one of the restaurants in the area, this is a good place to start!
author: Kimberly B.

description:
Aside from the interesting artwork on the walls, this bar (to me) offers nothing that other bars don't offer.
The crowd was mellow (it was a Sunday), and a couple was dancing to the jukebox tunes on the dancefloor. The bartender took his sweet time refilling my water (I had already been drinking all day prior), but was still a good, nice guy.

Eh, I honestly don't know if I would have known this place existed unless I casually strolled passed it like I did.
author: Alyssa G.

description: I actually liked this place. It wasn't too hipster/divey. The couches in the back were super comfy, I felt like a freshman in college all over again. The place gets pretty packed and the red lighting gets kind of annoying, like I'm in an artsy avant-garde film. The people here were more relaxed and friendly as opposed to the other bars around the area.
author: Phan H.

description: The bartender made us stiff drinks & didn't even charge extra $ when you say Hold the ice!  Maybe bc we went for HHour on a Wed & the place was empty, but I had fun!
author: Star B.

description:
Awesome location for bar and restaurant hopping!

Depending on who is DJing, this place can be packed! You can either have the window seat or the couches or booth seats further inside the bar. The couches remind me of the show Friends but in a bar setting :)

Lots of eyecandy on the wall. Bring your glasses or make sure your contacts are on!

Bartender can be super busy and drink might take a few minutes than usual. They need to add more bartenders during busy moments.
author: Elly G.

description: This place is a solid spot in the Mission. I always have fun here no matter what. All the bartenders and staff are really cool and nice. The people here are always really chill and nice. Just like anywhere in the Mission, its not exactly a classy joint, it is definitely a hole in the wall. My biggest complaint is that they don't carry any champagne. I always have to have a white wine spritzer when I come here, which is a decent substitute, but definitely not the same. Its a great place to start off the night, but also fun if you want to stay the whole night. Oh, and it is cash only :( which actually works out pretty nice for me because I rarely have cash, so other people have to buy my drinks! haha
author: Raheleh K.

description:
As much as I enjoy lame, limited beer selections and lazy, disinterested service, the real draw of Casanova Lounge, for me, is the cheesy velvet paintings adorning the walls. 

(N.B.: That sentence got progressively more sincere as it went on.)
author: Christopher R.

description:
The drinks are stiff, as are their hipster patrons, and I love it!

There is plenty of seating here, but if you go on a Friday night, expect to stand the entire time and fight your way through to order a drink. My favorite nights to go are Thursday nights. Friday and Saturday nights in the Mission are nightmares because everyone from the suburbs comes out to play.

They play cult-classic movies in the back via projection screen, and usually have a DJ spinning tracks from your indie playlist. 

The better-looking hipsters are here on Thursday nights, if they aren't at Zeitgeist.
author: Kristy H.

description:
The most amazing thing about this place is how unmemorable it is.

I've been sitting on this review for a while because I couldn't think of anything to say about it.

This is a boring bar in a neighborhood full of fun bars. I'd go back if someone wanted to but I'd never choose it.
author: Manny F.

description:
Casanova Lounge

When you walk in the doors, its dark, yet also warm and inviting at the same time. The place seemed to be pretty happening for a Friday night and the drinks were stiff and well-priced. This place looks a lot like its got some deep and dark dirty secret, and we all have some secrets, don't we? The mysteriousness of this place is what makes it so hip though. 

I felt like I was at a south congress party in Austin, but alas I was in San Francisco (or SF as the locals call it). 

We snagged the booth all the way in the back which was on a raised platform with some comfy faux leather couches for some solid people watching. I'd recommend a stop by to get a feel for some real gritty and hipster SF.
author: Amit K.

description: I would give the place -5 stars if I could, q but obviously that is not an option. One of my friends got attacked by the bar tender for his style choice (hello we are in SF and yes there are extroverted people in this city and that's why we live here) and my fiancée got shoved because we did not move according to their time schedule..,thrown out with fuck offs and grabbing shirts 15 min before closing. In other words: so don't waste your money or patience on this place. NOT WORTH IT!
author: Carolin B.

description:
Let's play "How long can the bartender act cool and not make drinks when there is a full bar of people looking at him to order".

I love that game.  

This place takes the cake.  I've never seen it so bad.  Seriously.  The cocktails were fine once they arrived.  The back is cool with all of the nude paintings and the multi-media projector displaying Motown footage.  That back area is not good for standing.

There isn't too much more to report other than it was so-so.

Don't half step.  If brown headed dewd is working with the hat, go somewhere else.
author: Brendon D.

description:
It's as if Alex's bar had more seating and was just a bar instead of a venue.  Oh and if it were in the bay area and about a million times more fun. 

2nd stop on my Mission birthday tour :)
author: Stephanie F.

description: I rediscovered this place just recently... Always good vibes every time I go back.. The selections, staff and vibe seems to be getting better since I used to go there years ago.... A good mix of people.....
author: Pietro S.

description: 15 years drinking in Casanova and i still love it... i know its not for everyone, but its a bar.... a proper bar with proper staff, good music... no bull.... great happy hour. it just works... maybe a little close to the action on valencia and gets crowded, but for me still has it all going on...
author: Reg B.

description:
Eh...  as often as I hear friends talk about how great this bar is, I'm indifferent.

They have the decoration down as the joint looks like a modern day harem turned booze hall while the sultan is away.  Like a requisite for the great pubs of England, the atmosphere is definitely here with any number of odd characters cavorting or talking in the nooks, crannies and couches of this place.

I guess ultimately I'm not big on the drinks or the service.  The "day" bartender who seemed to be getting off as we rolled in around 7:30 seemed like she could care less about serving drinks not to mention immediately serving randoms who just walked up instead of those of us waiting.  Not that I need a huge grin and some Ronald McDonald type of performance but at least seem like getting me a drink isn't akin to moving 50lb sacks of grain.  The drinks didn't seem like anything special and there really isn't anything unique or amazing on tap.  

There isn't anything wrong with Casanova per se but with bar competition in the Mission as stiff as the drinks, you have to do something to stand out.
author: Steven R.

description: I've been coming here so long that I don't even know how to explain why I like it so... The staff can seem surly at first approach, but they're actually quite personable when you give them a chance.  Drinks are served strong and are reasonably priced.  The decor is... interesting (velvet paintings of naked ladies) and the people watching is even more interesting.  While it can get crowded on weekend nights, there is a lot of seating, and you can usually grab a table or spot on the sofa if you loiter for a few minutes.  My favorite spot is the sofa in the very back of the room... perfect for watching the characters who wander in here.   The jukebox is pretty excellent and they have local DJs some nights.  Noise level can range from fairly quiet/average to extremely loud depending on the entertainment and time of day.
author: Heidi M.

description:
Hipster bar with a good chill vibe. 
Never let down by Cassanova. Can get kinda empty during the week at times but can also get pretty packed.

If you have ever partied in Los Angeles, it is exacty like The Cha Cha.
author: JJ C.

description: One of the few bars open at 3:30 on Friday.  We grabbed a seat by the window and watched people battle it out over parking spots.  Strong drinks, full bar, cash only.  Once it gets too hot by the front window, you can move to the dark back of the bar and stare at neon pictures of nude women.  Some of the nipples stare back.
author: Kathleen W.

description: Great lounge with beautiful lighting, comfy couches, great DJs,  and drink specials!  What else could one want?!  My new favorite spot.
author: Lorraine M.

description:
I think I end up here just about every time I come to the Mission.  Dark, sexy, decent strength drinks and nice beer selection. . . just bring your own make out buddy if that's what you're hoping for; it's not much the pick up joint despite its romantic name, though plenty of people seem to get smoochy on the couches.  Maybe the pictures of nekkid lady parts put them in the mood?
Like most bars - I prefer it on the quieter nights when I can park myself somewhere comfy and talk to my friends or dance around, vs. Friday and Saturday night where people are crowd farting (I HATE THAT) and bumping into you and spilling your drink.  And yet, I'm here on Friday or Saturday night more often then other nights.  Go figure.
author: Jennifer D.

description:
This lounge brings in a mixed crowd and that is good.  I get annoyed with a bar/lounge attracts only one set/group/type/clique of people.

The bartenders are nice, the decor is different, the feel is really chill.  I'd come back here if ever I can crash at someone's place after a night of drinking instead.  I wasn't wowed -- didn't hate it didn't love it.  I'm somewhere in between.
author: Kristin O.

description: I love this Dive Bar! Red lights, Velvet Paintings, quality Beer, strong cheap margaritas, jukebox, and dancing hipsters; ITS HEAVEN for a people watcher like me. A good spot to get hella tipsy and just chill, relax with the besties, and tell a few jokes.
author: Krystle S.

description:
I've rolled through Casanova any number of times, but last evening was the first time that I (a) showed up sober enough to render a proper judgment, and (b) left sober enough to be able to regurgitate my experience.

Let me show you it.

I met a friend for drinks, and got there a little early, around 6.  Casanova is set up like a mullet--all business in the front with the half-moon shaped bar right at the entrance--and the party in the back, with tables and lounging couches near the restrooms.

The bartender was really nice and called me "hon," which is a sure way to my wee heart.  She was really good about eye contact and communication, big smile, and while I and my friend just had pints, I saw her mixing up margaritas and BIG UPS for the handcraftsmanship.  Yay, bartender!

This is a bar that handles a crowd pretty well.  There's a lot of space for standing, some counter space, and a rounded bar means more room for customers, and less walking for the bartender, always a formula for success.

By the time I left, there was a crowd of about 25 or so, and the place still felt room, with lots of tables free, music had ramped up the volume a bit, but was still manageable.

And the creepy paintings of anonymous lounge lizards and 70s-style naked babes?  Icing.  Or gravy, if you prefer.  Gravy on the Casanova cake.

And I'm a man who likes his gravy.
author: Martin W.

description:
I reeeeeally want to like this place.

My best bud lives around the corner and it's usually our "meet up" spot before a night full of bad decision making. To be honest though, there isn't anything that would make me want to bring a friend or someone else here. I can't put my finger on it....
The bartenders are always super nice and friendly and when theres not a huge crowd I always find myself striking up a conversation but other than the nice people who work here I don't really have anything else to say.

Their deals and happy hour specials are awesome. Sometimes the crowd can get a bit on my nerves but that's just me ;)

Overall nice place good drinks decent people :)
author: Amanda S.

description: A staple of the mission neighborhood.  Perfect low lighting, awesome bouncers and bartenders.  Stiff drinks and good company.  Great eclectic decor and always an interesting collection of art.  What more could you ask for?
author: Cody P.

description: Glass grapes, mid century lighting fixtures, and nudes on black velvet. I love this place. Add the fairly priced drinks and I'm all in. Have stopped in with a number of friends and they all liked it too!!
author: George B.

description: Drinks were cheap...what more do I need to say!  Came in for a quick drink on a Friday night...the bar had a somewhat busy crowd.  The hightlight of this night was paying less than $11 for 2 drinks with one of them being top shelf.  Definitely a plus in my book and will definitely make another appearance should I be in the neighborhood!
author: Allison T.

description:
This place a bit weird. When I cane with a bunch of friends, there was a huge crowd just chilling in front with a homeless guy. It doesn't get any more ghetto than this. Inside was a bunch of sittin area with old school music from the 80's playing. Bunches of naked paintings on the wall an a projector showing random videos and images from the 80's. Drinks are alright. 

There are kind of a hippy like crowd and random people obviously flirting. I felt like I was sucked into the 80's with really bad flirting going on and random weird crazy people dance. 

Something you want to stop and see.
author: Jimmy H.

description:
A mainstay in The Mission.  Divey atmosphere (the toilets are some of the worst), cute bartenders and decent drinks.

Word to the wise, tho...if you come here on a date post-Yelp Elite event, don't tell your fellow Yelpers where you'll be.  They're likely to come stalk you and your date.
author: Melanie N.

description:
This is a pretty cool spot - good crowd, usually enough space - cool decorations - naked ladies a bit much but, hey it's SF. But, the bartenders are A-HOLES!  One night - after waiting 15 minutes for a drink - the bartender finally serves us. As she's handing the money back to my friend, my friend flips through and tries to gather a tip. Before my friend can put the money down the bartender says, "yeah, thanks a lot for tipping me" and walks away. My friend still tipped (2 dollars for 2 beers - that's pretty good... I was a bartender and it doesn't take much effort to pour a tap). I was floored by the service. Then they did last call at 1:30 AM! (probably because it takes the bartenders 30 minutes to get you a drink). Most other nights I wait an average of 15-20 minutes for service until I've finally realized - the hassle is not worth it. I won't be going to Casanova unless dragged. 

Get a new staff.
author: Hg4389 G.

description:
The owners of this place sure got the name right. It never fails, I come in and within 5 minutes I have some drunk guy hitting on me--even with someone else in tow.

Ah well, sometimes it is amusing, like the time the drunk Irish guy recited poetry (that I'm sure he cribbed from Robbie Burns or Yates) to me about my eyes.  He even managed to rhyme "hazel".  (Good on ya, mate, for that one.) 

Oh yeah, they have some KILLER fresh-lime margaritas in a pint glass for $7.  Sweeeeeet.
author: MakeUp M.

description:
Popped in here for a quick drink or 2 before dinner at Chay-Chay up the street. Met up with a couple of friends. Pretty chilled out, it was a Sunday night, so no drama, no crowds.

The decor is slightly bizarre, some will like it some will not (naked ladies on oil or velvet paintings, reddish hue to the whole place, couches, and a bar area).

Music was a-ok, nothing mind blowing, but you can talk, and hear others talk, which is cool if you wanna hear the party.

Drinks-wise, stuck to Fat Tire... which is pretty much good anywhere !
author: Shayan S.

description:
They have Magner's Cider and a kickin' juke box, so that alone would win at least a 3-4 star rating in my book automatically. 

On top of that, however, is the fact that I met my husband here nigh on 6 years ago, and every time I have been to Casanova -- both before and after meeting him -- I have enjoyed myself immensely. 

Sure, I could have easily just met another sleazebag, who broke my heart and left me to die, and that could have potentially had an impact on my review of this bar. 

Fate, however was a-lookin' out for both of us that night, Casanova my friend. As a result, 5 stars for you, and life-long bliss for me. Yippee!
author: Molly W.

description:
Who doesn't love to ogle velveteen portraits of naked ladies?

Answer: IDIOTS.

Thanks to my FAVORITE YELPER EVER, Sam S., I got to spend lots of time staring at the art on the walls at this weird hipster bro-bar. Yeah, I never knew hipster-bros existed, either. It's a new thing.

Now I feel like I have eye herpes.
author: Pamela D.

description:
Sex on the beach is usually amazing!  You know, the warm sand between your toes, the frothy waves crashing all around you..... okay, just kidding ;)  I'm talking about the drink.

This is generally one of those trusty drinks that is good at any bar. However, as GREAT as my first drink was at Casanova lounge, the second one was just as bad. Two nights, two drinks, and two very different opinions about this bar :\

The bartender last night hadn't even heard of a "Sex on the beach".. hasn't everyone heard of this??  I believe it was one of the first cocktails I ever ordered - right after turning 21. She attempted anyway, and it came out like cough syrup.  So gross!

I still like the atmosphere, but I ended up leaving after only 10 mins this time.  If I hadn't already been here before, I would have given them a 2 or 3.  So my average review for Casanova lounge is now about 3.5, lol. Hopefully my next experience here will bring the numbers back up!!
author: Laura W.

description:
I am not a big dive bar fan but Casanova has the right crowd and atmosphere for a good time. Mission is always a great area on a Friday night and it seems most people end up stopping by here. 

The place has a good vibe, nothing fancy or outrageous. People here are not the same douches that you will find in like Union Square, but chill people in jeans and t-shirts just sipping on a pint. The place itself is just a traditional bar with some eclectic collection of art, pictures, lighting, etc but the randomness works. Drinks are also quite cheap; I got 3 drinks and was pleasantly shocked the bartender only asked for $15. That in itself merits the place 3 stars.
author: Ed L.

description:
Not bad. They were playing what looked like some 70's surf video up on the screen, playing music so loud I had to yell to talk to my friends, and I can't remember what beer I got. Uh, what else? Comfy couches. Not too crowded, for a weekday. That is all.

Oh, I almost forgot to mention, as others have, about the velvet paintings of naked woman, on of which was being fondled by some dude. Uh, yeah.
author: Ken L.

description:
So, yeah, a meat market.  Except it's like a freaky black-market meat locker where you're buying "grade d, probably fit for human consumption" meat.

I like the atmosphere and the naked girls on velvet paintings covering the walls, and they often have good DJ's spinning fun tunes here, and if you can score the little back sconce area between the bathroom you're stoked, so long as the bathroom smell doesn't start wafting out.

But man, the skeezefest!  I always end up going here with my single girlfriends and we spend 5 minutes scoping the place out for hotties and it's just not happening.  Except that one cute guy who is in the corner sucking face with his girlfriend.

And then there was the time some coked out dude stole our friends' seat and tried to pick a fight with one of the girls in a group of about 7 girls who tried to get him to move (I was the only guy there and, swear to god, I was in the bathroom when all of this went down) and he was all "who's got your back, who's got your back huh?" And then when she was like "I've got my OWN back, asshole" he THREW HIS BEER ON HER!!

Tres Romantique.  The boys at Casanova really know how to woo a girl.
author: Kevin H.

description: Been going here for years... it is a standard in the area.  Gets packed on weekends, prices are affordable, but there is nothing ultra special about it. It has that dive wanna be kinda feel... which means that it is not quite a dive all the way because if it was a dive... it would be even cheaper. But it is a great place to go with a group of friends and throw a few back. I am sure I will keep going here for quite some time.
author: Amelia M.

description:
We headed off to continue the wondrous time that I call ..... "The Weekend of Heat".  Yes, the past weekend saw SF and the surrounding Bay Area wrapped in a blanket of lovely, steamy 90 degree love. Ice cold beers were in demand and clothes got sparse. We were celebrating B's birthin' day and by the time we got to Casanova there were plenty of friends there waiting to pour her  the liquid-age-reverser of her choice.

I'll give her this, the girl can drink. She got shit-housed and kept em' coming. The thing is, she hates heels but wore these 5 inch calf-killing monsters the whole night and her 6'2" ass hadn't toppled over once by Midnight. I made some bets to see who'd be the person that "bought the shot that brought down the rock." But hell no! That girl's liver is made of granite! Goddamn if she didn't Sum-bitchin' drink all those damn drinks and titter-todder home under her own steam. 

Back to the bar. Casanova is a hipster hang-out. Mother-Hefer me timbers .....  if every mop-headed bastard in the place was wearing a plaid print shirt with dumb ass tattoos and boa-constrictor tight pants legs stickin' out everywhere. Whatever .... at least most of the people there smelled like they had bathed recently. Thank you hipsters for embracing the concept of western hygiene on a Friday night. 

We did have one bad experience. A big Rasta dude got totally messed up  ..... walked over to our table and basically fell, or rather passed out, on my friend Anna. Poor girl. All I saw were little wiggly hands and feet sticking out from under this huge pile of dreadlocks. Thank God, I was sober enough to pick up this heavy Bob Marley looking bastard and walk him out the door. There is no doorman of which to speak of so I play bouncer and set this weed-smelling mess against the wall outside where he can drool and jibber-jabber to himself to his heart's content. I walk inside and inquire at the bar... "Where's the doorman?"  The tiny cute bartender gives me a blank look. OK .... self serve bouncer night it shall be! 
Poor Anna, for the remainder of the night she's totally gun shy and inches away from anyone that teeters close to her.

The rear of Casanova has lounge type seats and tables in the back. There is a semi-circular bar in the front area. It's not a big place ... but definitely somewhere you and some hipster friends can hang out and yell at one another over the music. Beers are mostly tap, and they only carry one bottle brand, can't remember what though (hee hee). Shots being the mainstay of the day. Beware the smokers outside and the bathrooms inside, both stink worse than a huge freakin' dump, covered in a big ol' pile of crap, soaked in a jug of week old farts. and lit on fire.

Other than that, laugh at the table cloth shirt mafia, and avoid the leaning tower of Rasta .....  Enjoy the DIVE.
author: Mark B.

description:
velvet paintings... $5 PBR and Jameson shots...

how can you go wrong!?
author: Milagro J.

description: Mediocre drink mixing but cool atmosphere. The paintings actually DO have artistic merit; they're not JUST hot, naked chicks. That said, they combine with the red lighting and walls to create a sexy mood. There aren't any dark corners to slip into so you'll like want to head elsewhere when it's time to "slip into something more comfortable."  ;)
author: Bill B.

description:
A little crowded on the weekends BUT what can you expect? Its in the mission.

good bar, good music, good looking folks.

The bartender named Nuri is awesome! She makes a mean margherita.
author: emmie h.

description:
I can't remember a truly awesome time I've had in there since my good friend Mike stopped working there. Those days were super fun. But alas, I do end up here on occasion, and it is somewhat pleasant. But I prefer the other bars in the area, really. This place has too much of a scene at times, gets too crowded on the weekends, and is really far too dark (which is also sometimes its appeal).

This is a rather wishy-washy review. Hence the wishy-washy 3 star rating.

Casanova does have a special place in my heart because it is the only bar in the SF Bay area where I once kissed a girl.
author: Rachel F.

description:
I was first hesitant on going to the Casanova Lounge for New Years when my old high school buddy approached me with the idea of attending a toga party there. 

After all, how much fun can we have? This is a group of drunken thirty year olds, wrapped up in bed sheets, wandering the Mission with the promise of having some "Old School" style hilarity.

Ok, my hesistation probably didn't last more than 2 seconds.... "I'm there dude!"

So, New Years Eve... already pre-loaded with alcohol at my friends' apartment and armed to the teeth with "water bottles" for our trip to Casanova, we arrived at the lounge in our party attire ready to have fun.

The bar was starting to fill up at this point and a looped projection of Animal House played next to a collection of nudie pictures on the wall. Some people decided to show up in regular attire, while the more festive patrons were running around in their togas.

Our group found ourselves swinging and dancing to some great party hits of the 60's and 70's like Wooly Bully, Gloria, and of course... Shout!

More shots...
More dancing...

Countdown... Happy New Years!!

shots
dancing

Ok, it's time to go when the sweaty toga wearing frontman starts diving into the crowd.

Great night

Huh? No "Old School" style hilarity? Wait for it....

Buddy disappears right after the countdown and pukes 3 times on way home.

Drunken buddy pisses off a group of BART riders.

Yours truly streaks off on foot into the Daly City night.

There we go.

Happy New Years 2009!
author: Sam T.

description:
This is a very pretty bar.. but as you can see a trend is happening with all my reviews of bars in the city.. I'm ALWAYS really intoxicated when I go to any bar there. So everything looks good to me/places start to mesh together.

But I do remember casanova being very cool. I enjoyed being able to lounge with friends and socialize with new people in a not so barish setting. Mixed crowd most of the time, lots of fun!
author: Debbie P.

description:
I mean, I like this place. There isn't really anything not to like. It's relatively chill on the weekdays, really buzzy on the weekends, which turns it more into a bar than a lounge. The drinks are reasonably priced and stiff enough to smack me around a little. I think what makes people say that it's not all that memorable or that they dont have the inclination to bring friends here is the fact that it's a bit inconsistent of a spot. The general ambience is loungey, sofas and chairs, naked lady paintings, velvet, dim lighting, what have you. But the crowd can get pretty rowdy, I do agree on the higher than average number of dudes trying to mack on drunk chicks. The music is way too loud for this place to call itself a lounge. 

But hey. You're in the midst of bar town. Hop in, hop out.
author: Chieh T.

description:
Since my initial review, I went through a brief love affair with this place, which has now turned sour. 

It was all peaches and cake after I frequented the place a few times and grew to love the mission. This was about 2 years ago. Casanova was a staple in my nights out. 

Fast forward to last Friday night, taking some visitors out in the mission. I actually thought, "anywhere but Casanova would be fine." My how things have changed. This place has turned into an extension of the Medjool or Blondie's crowd on the weekends. If you like either of those places, it's probable you no idea what I'm talking about. 

Either way, during the week, this place is still a-ok by me but weekends are to be missed.
author: Angela N.

description:
Neighborhood bar
even if you live across town
art work keeps you interested
in this low light setting
it has a feel of a victorian living room
friendly servers
author: Po L.

description:
#1 on my 5 Best Margaritas in SF list!

A margarita should be served in a pint glass (or a big fat margarita glass) with fresh lime juice, and a whole lotta love...that's what you get at Casanova. Plus some awesome decor replete with velvet oil paintings and a great DJ (if the DJ ain't there the jukebox is pretty tasty also).
author: Josh C.

description:
This place combines 3 of my very favorite things...

Boobs
Vintage Lamps
Cheap, strong drinks

Hard to go wrong with a bar that embraces all of them and also supplies a yummy leather couch, a cool crowd and a great location. I liked this place and all of the nudie pics and the cool glass grape lamps. They also make a mean Greyhound and the bathroom wall provides a lot of interesting reading material :)

Good times and cash only
author: Stephy S.

description:
Why is it every time I walk in this place I meet some jackass who thinks he actually IS Casanova? 

Dude, you are just a cheesy horny guy who spent too much time looking at naked photos over a few cocktails in a dimly lit trendy bar, so back off!!!
author: Drue C.

description:
At the sixth bar of Christmas I bought myself for me:
One PBR
One PBR
One Jack and Coke
One PBR
One vodka Red Bull
One pint of PBR
This bar is sleazeball alley - in other words, right up my alley.
Being single is fun to do....
I've always had a great time flirting here - it's contagious.
The horshoe-ish bar can sometimes make for intolerable waits, but that's life.
The couches:pimp.
The art: pimp.
The people: pimp.
The conversations: pimp.
The bathrooms: CRACKED!
author: Theo R.

description:
Yo, shorty, It's my birthday
We Yelpers partied like it's my birthday
We effin gulped bacardi like it's my birthday
And you know we don't give a fuck cuz it's my birthday'


All I know is there were cupcakes, endless supplies of vodka, and plenty of cute boys. And it was my birthday. I have always been a fan of Casanova and last night made me fall in love for real. The crowd is definitely less hipster than it has been in the past and the bartenders are on top of things. Thank you, thank you, thank you Yelpers for making my birthday so special (Stephan- you are the best for bringing me cake) and thank you Casanova for being big enough to accomadate all of us. 

This is a great neighborhood bar. It gets a little packed as the evening wears on, though, so go early! It's a little man-heavy, but at least they're cute men. Thank you, bartenders, for the special pink birthday shots! Decent music, doorman hot enough that I kissed him, and strong drinks make me want to come back for more soon!!! Well worth the trip to the Mission but don't even think about driving!! You will spend most of your night looking for parking...(Thanks, Starla, for driving) 
**The nekkid pics on the wall don't hurt, either. Ben's friends are hot and I think they may be regulars...
author: Autumn K.

description: Stopped in here on a weekday evening, ordered a rum & coke and was charged $6... was it happy hour?   or are they normally that cheap?  Either way, I'm impressed and will definitely return.  So sick of paying $10+ for a drink in the Mission, nice to find a bar that is keepin' it real.
author: Joyce J.

description:
I kinda don't get it. . .weeknights are pretty alright here, but I usually don't end up at Casanova on a Monday (I have responsibilities, people! There's TV to watch!) This is yet another Mission bar that turns into douche bag, Sally n' Nancy- just-re-highlighted-their-blond-hair-blonder, central. Which I guess is cool, but, um, not really.

The bathroom smells fucking gross, this weird combo of bubblegum and Nag Champa. Eeeeeew. The crowd absolutely stupefies me, and I'm motherfucking smart as hell. This we can all agree on, right? You know, my intelligence. 

Shut up, back there. I hear you.

Anyway, the bartenders are rad and I think one of the ladies also works at Hemlock. I see her at metal shows and appreciate her swift drink-pourin' disposition. 

But something just ain't quite right with Casanova and I'm having trouble figuring out exactly why. Perhaps the douchey clientele, in addition to the nauseating bathroom scent, in conjunction with the odd table layout that somehow reminds me of high school prom? 

Ahh, and they don't serve cheap bottled beer. Curses!
author: Chloe S.

description:
When I'm feeling tired and whacked out from a long day participating in the San Francisco Hipster Olympics, I would certainly kick it with a beer at the Casanova.

No, there's no official after party...that's because after parties are for babies (which is ironic, because one of the mandatory requirements for being a hipster includes having the attitude and social graces of a toddler).

I liked the music, the seating and the rosy red hue of the mood lighting that made me feel like I was in some kind of Eastern European opium den. The Casanova is my favorite bar in the city, at least for today. Because if Vice decides that sports bars are the new dive bar, I might have to re-think my entire life.
author: Carrie E.

description:
If you can come here when it's not crowded (i.e. not on Friday/Saturday night) it's pretty awesome. I like the decor - my personal favorite is the Michael Jackson female nude painting.

I love the bartenders. They have always been friendly and interactive. I once had a girl who would not stop trying to make booty calls, so the bartender helped me compose a text message to dissuade her, haha.

I have to take a star off because I made the mistake of ordering the most awful martini I've ever tasted. I don't know what I was thinking ordering a cocktail from Casanova, but it's all good.
author: Ryan V.

description:
I bartend.  Not to blow my own trumpet (wouldn't it be cool if you could, tho?) but I do it really well - I also dabble in extreme smart-ass-osity - I can give it and I love to take it.  What I do not enjoy is gratuitious shit-giving 'specially from fellow service workers.   My irritation level was on orange-alert when I tried to get an after-shift drank last night from the skills and manners-challenged school of bartending.  

Not worth going into detail, but if there is another ride on the "nasty attitude express" believe me when I tell you that I will fucking cut you, ya hear?  Now, go take a yoga class - it will do wonders for your attitude and, possibly, your ass.

That said, the other bartender was a cutie-pie and was so much less tortured.  I dig the decor, music, and I loves the prices so I may be back for another swing.  Maybe Mr. Grouchy was just having a bad night.
author: Mokirobinson M.

description:
its a bar that screams debauchery and sex ... the naked lady paintings , the sexy turquoise candles ( anyone who knows me knows that im sold if anything is that colour!) and the occassional cute bar man ! .... mmmm ! 

Awesome tunes, cheap drinks eclectic furniture. 

Yep ill be back .... and you will be waiting !
author: Amy W.

description: I have been here a couple of times and neither time I really had a choice. I am not to fond of the casanova lounge as I think there are so many other great places in the Mission and it's a mystery to my why people would chose to go here (unless they don't really know where else to go). There is nothing really that makes this bar super bad, but also nothing that makes this bar great. The bouncers can be strict and the drinks watered-down.
author: Jennifer H.

description:
Pretty good seating set-up. I love naked girls on the walls. Decent pours and reasonable prices. However, the swing shift bartenders sucked. Not only could they not keep up with the 7-8o'clock crowd, but I think they had ADD also...ladies the object is to sell drinks not shoot the poo with people giving your their CD's and others at the bar.

The night 'tenders definately turned it up a notch and were right on it!

Decent spot all-in-all
author: Patrick G.

description:
i REALLY like this bar when its empty.  A nice slow weeknight, maybe a happy hour, or even a birthday that falls on a Wednesday (my first time here was my 27th.), make this place tolerable and actually quite enjoyable.  There is usually a DJ bumpin kickin toons, and bartenders pouring healthy drinks.  There are plenty of areas to sit, barstools, cozy couches, or even a lil nook in the back if you want it to be a bit more intimate with your group or you wanna go in the back and make out with your honey.

Now....cut to the weekend.  The Mission changes as a whole and that is definitely shown at Casanovas as well as the other bars.  It gets uber crowded.  The bartenders become much slower, and the likely-hood that you can sit to make-out with your honey is a lot lower, you might have to resort to standing against a wall...which isn't necessarily a bad thing.  Realistically this bar is better than many in the mission on a Friday night.  Just expect to get smooshed
author: Lauren F.

description:
I don't stop here every time I pass by, but I do press my face up against the window and breathe heavily through my nose to get some T-Rex Jurassic Park action up in there to show how much i love the place.  

Blame It On The CASANOVA!! ow!
author: Kelly H.

description:
Casanova is one of my favorite bars in the city. The red lights, tables, velvety couches, small (but not Beauty Bar status) size, and of course the naked women on the walls make for a great drinking environment.

But I came here this past Saturday and wanted to swear off the mission and Casanova for good. Waking up still sad from my previous night's disappointing excursion, I came to my senses and realized i was only kidding myself if I thought I would never come back here. I'm just going to chalk it up to bad luck. The rain brought out the most annoying/whack/cracked crowd I have ever experienced at Casanova .

Lesson learned: Casanova and the mission are at its best during the week or on a Sunday (I remember Sunday Soul Night here a while back and it was terrif). Also, if it's pouring, definitely don't go out (or at least not to the mission) because the LA's (lame asses) are out in full force.

Note: Bring a Sharpee for the bathroom.
author: Jackie M.

description:
I've come to hate kitsch. We like kitsch because it makes us feel superior; We build ourselves up by mocking someone else's poor taste. It appeals to our insecurity and pettiness and I wish we (myself most of all) were bigger than that.

That said, I like Casanova. Good drinks, comfortable couches, a fun, unpretentious atmosphere and crowd. Oh, and paintings of topless women. It can take a while to get a drink and things may not always go well for you here but you'll probably have a good time.

update: actually, I love kitsch. I hate myself for loving it and I wish I were big enough to hate it like I claimed I did, but the reality of it is that mocking people for having less refined tastes is FUN. damn it, I wish I were a better person.
author: matthew r.

description:
You call yourself Casanova, so you hang bad paint-by-numbers of naked ladies on your walls...

What exactly does that mean?

You're a cheeseball.
author: Lisa T.

description:
Halfway down the street and opposite Limon, is the Casanova Lounge. When a friend suggested we head down to the Mission for a drink, we avoided Delirium and headed down here instead.

The bar wraps around from the front, and there are low couches and tables in the back. The patrons look interesting, but there are precious few of the beautiful people. My friend and I ended up getting hit on by a group of middle aged women, which was both humorous and tragic. One of the few times I've had to turn down amorous attentions and a drink - on principle. The music got louder as the night wore on, which made conversation difficult, but at least the drinks were a normal size and reasonably priced. The bartenders were competent and efficient.

Major con: The restroom looks like the homeless people outside have been using it on a regular basis, and to keep you from noticing the filth, the regular bulb has been replaced by a red light. If Mars had a restroom defiled by SF bums, this is what I'd expect it to look like. C'mon guys, clean this shit up. Literally.
author: Maxx L.

description:
This bar is oh-kayyyyyyy.  I hadn't been here in over a year and one of my good friends wanted to go here for his birthday last weekend.  By the time I arrived after 11pm, most of my friends were already trashed.  There were a lot of "I love you's", intermittent dancing and I had about three full drinks spilled on me.  If I had been a little more liquored up, I probably would have been one of the culprits too.  I enjoyed the $2.50 draft PBR and the bartenders were friendly although busy.  Some of the music was good, I enjoyed singing along to "All the Young Dudes".

BUT, there was a strange mix of people here and quite A LOT of toolbags.  My friend put her drink down to look for her phone in her handbag and when she looked back, it was empty.  One of the guys at the table said "Oh, that was my drink.  Here's your drink" pointing to the drink now sitting in front of him.  And she was like "I DON'T think so."  

He offered to buy her a new one so she followed him to the bar.  However, when they got up to the bar he started chatting up some other girl.  She ended up just ordering a drink herself.

Another toolbag told me that I looked tense and tried to give me a shoulder rub.  Then, I realized I WAS TENSE BEING THE PRESENCE OF ALL THESE ASS CLOWNS.  It was then that I decided to leave.  Once I was back on the street in the cold night air, I felt much better.  F***, I need a massage.
author: Rosie F.

description:
The game they play in there is really stupid --- who I want to fight, f*** or marry! The guy in there actually was trying to convince me over a few drinks that the game is awesome and brings a certain atmosphere to the place --- I disagreed and maybe that's why I left the place alone :-) 

LOVED the paintings --- erotic paintings, photography, etc get my vote right away! They also make some good drinks so plus to that! 

DJ the night I was there truly sucked...I was almost embarrassed how bad he mixed, yikes!

In any way, the place was packed with some good looking people --- I had a blast!
author: Katja S.

description:
I would like to give 3 1/2 starts to Casanova but we all know that's not an option. 

Here's what I liked. Despite the fact that it was mega busy, I did not have to wait long for drinks. The drinks were cheap. The drinks were 80% vodka 20% soda. Yeah, that's awesome. I also really liked, loved even, the lighting. Very sultry lounge but I guess that's what I should expect with a place called Casanova. I feel like I could get my Casanova on, or someone else can work their Casanova on me easily with that lighting.

Here's what I did not like. Frat crowd. Loud-ass music.
author: C P.

description:
I love this spot.  On the week days.  I adore the couches, the rad naked chick decor, and the drinks are stiff.  Perfect.

DO NOT COME ON THE WEEKENDS!  I made the HORRID mistake of going with a gentleman friend on a Saturday eve.  It was over run with yahoos.  I could not get a seat, and getting to the bar felt like a Red Hot Chili Peppers concert, circa 1997.  When my friend went to the bathroom, it was like vultures circling-  about 5 guys descended on me, and began chatting me up in a yucky, "Swingers" sort of manner.

Otherwise, this is one of my fave bars.
author: Jennifer O.

description:
"The faculty of bringing back a wandering attention   is the very root of judgement, character and will"  ..William James, pioneer American psychologist.

I have a limited attention span and whenever I enter a new bar, I usually make a quick judgement   whether I would be sufficiently stimulated or I should quickly move on to the next one. I enter Casanova, and quickly give it one star for being named after a such a role model. My critical eyes rove to the rear of the bar and I spot some deep comfy couches and I quickly sink myself into one.

I start sipping a well-made   vodka cranberry and start engaging in conversation with my friends when I suddenly spot the nude pictures (of women) draped all over the walls. Having lost my train of thought, my attention is drawn towards the nudes. What is most striking about them is the tautness of the nipples.

The more my attention is focused on the nipples, the more taut they seem to become. Is the presence of my sexy self turning the nudes on? Or the process of increasing attention is increasing the depth and detail of visual perception in my mind? Isn't the difference between animate and inanimate objects just the quantum of energy fields? 

Suddenly I am struck by a jolt of orgasmic epiphany. I realize that most of the time in life there are no right answers,  only right questions.
author: Kaustav C.

description:
Went here with my boyfriend's family before we all went to dinner... This place was at first overwhelming with all the "tiki type" inspired decorations combined with spanish cartoonish pictures framed on the walls, but it ended up being pretty fun there for a few drinks. The drinks were yummy and affordable. The place was pretty packed and friendly also. It wasn't too loud either with their music, so we could all talk and catch up.

I don't go to the Mission often, but if I'm in the area again with my boyfriend to visit his brother, it'd be fun to go back there for a quick drink on the way to somewhere again...
author: Jessica P.

description:
I spend a lot of time at Cassanova, and not just because I live so close by. It's a great bar for meeting friends and strangers, and the bartenders pour some serious drinks.

Cool and eccentric jukebox as well. Sometimes the locals are a little hipper than thou? So what, a bar should be surly at times!
author: John B.

description: The bartenders here are fast! They actually seem to notice you waiting and so they quickly pump out the drinks. Another thing I noticed is at the end of the bar, they offer free access to plastic cups and a pitcher of water. Great idea!
author: Lubs Y.

description:
Like a math teacher turning into a werewolf, Casanova transforms from calm dark cave of local intoxication to braying mob of hook up sleaze whenever the moon rises.  It has always been this way, and if it weren't for the juke box and mellow early evening I'd not go here at all.   Great jukebox - teen beat, garage, surf, weird foreign garage/surf.  Nice bartenders, good beer selection and enough black velvet paintings to make a collection.  Best of all a breezy window seat looking out onto Valencia for a pleasant afternoon beer. All ruined by bad fashion, bad pick up lines, and leg humping.

Casanova is a perfect example of why 16th and Valencia can't have nice things.
author: Gustie L.

description:
Yeah you can't help but love the nakie pictures on the wall, but thats all my alcohol saturated brain could retain from my experience at Casanova.

The room was dark, and dare I say funky? I can see it working for small groups (since the seating was pretty cool), or maybe a slightly creepy date, but for fun night out, not so much.

Don't get me wrong if you want a more mild Saturday night it would be OK. The drinks are good, the bar tenders are attentive, you can hold a conversation, and the music was pretty good. But because of the atmosphere my overall impression was "Eh".
author: rachel c.

description:
It's a nice bar, however I will be permanently scarred by what happened to me here a few months ago.  My friends call this The Chupacabra Incident.

It was a busy weekend night, the place is packed.  My two friends and I find a spot by the bar, and I claim the only available bar stool.  We hang out chatting for a while when this rather large woman with a little tiny straw hat perched on her head walks up and stops next to us.  I make some comment about how that hat would look comical on my friend.  She smiles and kind of stares off into the distance.  I resume my conversation.

A few minutes later I feel someone pressing into my back (I'm sitting sideways to the bar).  I figure it's just because of how packed the place is, and ignore it.  The pressing increases, and now she's completely behind me when she starts rubbing my back...and slipping an arm around my waist.  My friends finally notice and start cracking up.  I'm trying to maintain composure with no clear escape route in sight, I turn around and ask "may I help you?".  I guess she interprets this as me turning around to kiss her, and I dodge that bullet by mere inches.

My friends, meanwhile, being such the good buddies that they are, decide to leave for the bathroom and leave me alone with the Chupacabra.  I don't even remember what I mumbled as I ran out of that bar.

Great drinks and atmosphere though.  Maybe I'll come back once the scars of my molestation heal.
author: Eugene F.

description:
I never thought of myself as a "hipster" (note: I am using my fingers for the quotes).  But recently I was told I was while sitting in this bar. Before I pounded my fist down on the table in rage, I looked around and noticed that I too was dressed in skinny black jeans, hoodie, ironically nerdy sneakers, and yup standard issue black frame glasses. 

crap.

I asked for a fat tire and they gave me something else, but it was beer and it was frosty, and I'm not picky. Plus, it looks really seedy and awesome in there. No wonder the place is called Casanova... I felt like I was being seduced by the bar itself, with it's black velvet paintings of boobies, candle light, and red-red glow. 

You know what? I kinda liked it.
author: Nnekay F.

description:
Come for the :
-cheap happy hour - 7 days a week until 7pm. We orderd 1 PBR, 1 Mac 12 on the rocks, 1 Manhattan - $14.50. Nuff said. Deal of the century.
-no frills, dark red light special lighting - you can probably not put your face on and be okay
-the crowd is no frills either - leave your 'ttude at home
-CASH ONLY - leave your CC's at home. Bring a wad of dollars and drink until you run out. Then you know it's time to go home. 
-Spacious

**I'm too tired to justify why it's a 3 and not a 4, 5, ---but apparently Alan N. has called me out on no diversifying my stars. So...Alan N. - SUCK IT!*** =) Sidenote, Alan N. is my relative.
author: Jessica C.

description:
Ugh... this place is terrible. I was there on a Tuesday night and waiting about 10 mins per drink. The bartenders here are the worst. They don't have a freaking clue how to serve people quickly or work the full bar. 

Basically, they're like a lot of bartenders in SF in that they are probably doing it because they think it's a cool job and not because they have any skill or take any pride in what they do. At one point some of the bartenders' friends came into the bar and they served them all immediately despite all the other people that had been angrily waiting for a while. They even stopped to have a drink with their friends! Unbelievable. 

This place was pretty bad on a Tuesday night with a moderate crowd, I can't imagine how unbearable it must be during busier nights. One extra star for the hot nekkid ladies on the wall.
author: Aaron V.

description:
It's likely that I'm a pretty easy mark for a lounge like Casanova:  dark, ambient, engaging cadre of beers on tap, they know how to mix a cocktail if that's your poison.  

The recent night I stopped in saw a heavy pack of locals huddled in comfy confines, and you got the distinct impression that the casual neighborhood bar concept wasn't foreign to these folks.  It's definitely a hang out, predicated on the casual, cool evening, and throughly different from the put-on you might find at other places.

I'll be back.
author: Kevin N.

description:
So!  Went to Casanova Saturday night to wish a friend happy birthday with about eight other people!  There are kitschy paintings of naked women on the walls!

It was fun ... kinda.  The company was great, the service was actually pretty good, and the drinks were fairly strong, but there was something about the place that kind of bugged me.  Like, when you buy some cream and, just before you pour it in your coffee, something kind of smells "odd."  Then you check the expiry date, see that it's still "good," and proceed to pour.  Then you drink said coffee, and what do you know?  You've kind of psychically talked your subconscious into believing that the coffee is "off."  That didn't make an ounce of sense, did it?  That's okay, 'cos all you need to know is that there are a lot of paintings of naked women on the walls.

Nina and I ended up circumnavigating the congested confines of the bar, taking in each and every "exhibit."  She pointed out the fakes and I pointed out the ones that were just plain inhuman.  "That one," I said, "looks like two pregnant Great Dane teats."  There were torpedoes, apples, pumpkins, and porn queen ta-tas, but only a couple could actually be said to resemble USDA 100% natural boobs.

There were a lot of paintings of naked women on the walls.  That, my friends is why I give it three stars instead of merely two.  Yay, paintings of naked women!
author: Thomas B.

description: Small but awesome lounge with ton of personality. Feels very uniquely San Franciscan, almost like what you would get if a Hindu monk with a liking for nude art opened a bar (there are nude photos adorning every wall). Bargain drinks, especially the giant $7 margaritas.
author: Zach H.

description:
I thought I hated Casanova, but turns out I like it.  A lot.  

There are tall people here.  I'm not hating on the shorties, but in the midwest I am average height and in SF I am an amazon.  There were alot of giants here.  Made me feel at home.  And that blonde dj chick was spinnin' mad oldies.  I love the mash potato.
author: Alexis M.

description:
I've only been here twice but I dig it.

Drinks are strong and cheap. Vibe is laid back and cozy.  

I adore the leather couches - perfect for an impromptu smooch-fest with my date ... said date adored the naked lady pictures hanging all around.  

You lose one star for the atrocious bathroom.  disgusting.  seriously.
author: Sarah K.

description:
You know that tip so many public speakers supposedly swear by? The one about picturing everyone naked? Yeah, you know the one I'm talking about. Well, it never worked for me until I paid a visit to Casanova. 

Oh, the nudity abounds with nowhere for your eyes to avert except to another painting of..well...more nudity. Surrounded by such lack of inhibition, how could anyone not suddenly feel more confident? It's not just something that works for me, obviously. You won't have any trouble running into a hipster version of Mr. Casanova himself here. 

Speaking of which, the hipsters thrive here. You'd think there was an American Apparel shop operating in the back. But isn't that anywhere in the Mission these days? 

Get here early on the weekends because the party won't wait for you to get started. The music is good here--though it could get kinda loud---and you're not the only one who knows it. For a different feel and more breathing room, try coming Mon-Wed nights. It'll feel a lot more comfy...and you might even be able to have your pick of the seating.

And when you are here, don't forget to say hello to my special lady on the wall. She's the one in the back right corner. Facial features resemble Michael Jackson. 

You can't miss her.
author: Rona J.

description:
I'd give this place 3.5 stars if I could, but I can't and the tiny part of me that is occasionally generous and optimistic COMPELS me to round it up to 4. Don't spend it all on one place Cassanova Lounge.

Unsurprisingly, the place was packed when my buddy Jon and I walked in at about 11:30 on a saturday night. Somehow he managed to snag us a couch in that little alcove at the back of the room (perhaps by selling his soul to the devil? I was genuinely flabbergasted that he found us a place to sit.) while I fought my way to the bar and got us some drinks. We sat and sipped and surveyed the place, and both came to the conclusion that the best thing about the place is probably also the worst.

Don't get me wrong, I like paintings of hot naked women as much as the next straight guy, but there's one hanging pretty much everywhere you look and I found it difficult not to stare at them. Not difficult, actually. Impossible. I'm sure this made me seem even more charming than usual to all the real live ladies in the vicinity. 

*sigh*

But apart from (or perhaps in addition to-- your call) this, the place has cool atmospheric lighting and a vibe that is above dive bar but below Marina-inspired-douche-locker, which makes it pretty awesome.
author: Jonathan A.

description: A decent place to chill and have a good pint of guinness.
author: Anuj K.

description:
Don't go if you're looking for a big, swanky night on the town, but go if you're looking for a cool bar with a fun atmosphere to grab a beer with some friends. The walls are hung with paintings of nude ladies (one that looks remarkably like Michael Jackson), and there are nice leather couches and tables everywhere. 

And plus, they were playing the movie Fubar in the background, and that kinda made it for me. Best movie ever, eh :)
author: Sarah K.

description:
I used to come here when I was younger and didn't know any better, but now that I'm older and somewhat wiser, I see this place for what it really is.  It's a bar full of pretentious assholes and shitty bartenders.  The doorguy is usually an ass and there's no place to sit or stand because it's a snugglefest with a bunch of people that you wouldn't throw a shoe at.
Jennifer O said it right about this crowd:  a bunch of yahoos indeed.
author: Meh M.

description: They took down my other review but I still love this place. I read other reviews about bad service and being present for one of the "bad times that were had" can say that that guy is a total ass. Great place great bartenders. Nuff said.
author: Mikel R.

description:
Dude.

Hot as fuck.
Saw old hook-up.
Crazy crowded.

Three strikes you're out. 

The bartenders made up for it though.  Those girls kicked ass.  They get the stars. 

Honestly though..it felt like a crowded sauna.  

Hint for the manager or rather owner.....air conditioner.  Look into it.

Seriously, I hate Fridays in the Mission.
author: Jay H.

description:
The last stop on an all-night bar-crawl for A-Train's 9th annual 21st birthday.  

So far, I think it's my fav. bar in the mission.  Nice and unpretentious, and the bartenders were very friendly to our big DRUNK group.  They didn't even mind the blow-up doll antics.

Perhaps we just weren't offensive enough.

Also, I seem to remember the place being quite large.

Finally, I agree with Johannes B:

Abgefahrene Bar. Von aussen versifft, von innen hui.  Man kommt einfach ins Gespraech mit den Leuten.
author: Rocco B.

description:
Loud indie music always rocks my boat, but if you're a single gal expecting to hold deep and meaningful conversations with McDreamy... 

Lower your expectations. Just smile and nod politely, act like you are interested in hearing him yelp about his cool ass bitchin' Camaro and you'll be fine.... and after 3 shots of tequila and 5 Pacificos later, the conversation won't really matter much, will it?

A good choice if you're bar hopping around town. At 2 o'clock in the morning when Mr. Chode the bartender tells you it's time to go home 'cause the party is O-V-E-R, I can almost hear Semisonic playing in the background...

Closing time... one last call for alcohol, so finish your whiskey or beer
Closing time... you don't have to go home but you can't stay here...

I know who I want to take me home... So gather up your jackets and move it to the exits, I hope you have found a friend... 

Lalalalala...

Okay, so not really.... Did I mention the music they play in there is good?
author: NirvAnna M.

description:
Bwahahahahahaha!  Hee hee.  Oh, this place just tickles me.

It was pretty apparent when my friend and I walked in that this would not be our scene.  First of all, at 25 and 26 respectively, the both of us felt immediately, without a question, Old.  Captial O.  Despite how obvious it was we didn't belong here, we couldn't tear ourselves away, the scene was just too sociologically fascinating.

It was a pick-up extravaganza!  There were transparent bows-and-arrows of glances going back and forth throughout the room.  Since my old friend and I were obviously invisible, thus safe, we could kind of sit back on a plush couch in the corner and make a game of guessing who would glance at who and what glance would lead to a conversation and which conversation would fall on its face.  It was great fun - you can't play this game just anywhere.  Oh but there was something sad about it, too.  Not sustainable.  We left after finishing out admittedly tasty drinks.

Did I go on a bad night?  Like maybe this was a stop on a college-sponsored pub crawl?  I don't know - it's called Casanova after all, and there are naked lady paintings all over.  It's got that take-me-out-to-the-alley(but maybe let's take a cab to the Marina and find an alley there)-and-lets-share-STD's sort of orangish glow about it.  Yeah, not my scene from what I've seen.
author: Jennifer B.

description:
I went here last night by accident, we were on our way somewhere else, and I had to use the bathroom so we popped in, and decided to stay.
It was dark and I loved all the light fixtures hanging around, There were couches and comfy looking chairs. We only stayed for a drink, but I would like to go back, the only thing was the crowd seemed young and I'm not that old.
author: JIll H.

description:
A few lovely ladies and I grabbed drinks here last night, and it was just precious! The vibe was super chill, and who doesn't enjoy booby artwork adorning the walls? I could barely keep my head in the conversation because I was so distracted by all the ta-tas.

I can't comment on the mixed drinks, which I hear are great, because I went for the standard "poor kid special": $2.50 PBR. 

Minus 1 star for the super loud music. I dunno, but if you're going to have a lounge-y type atmosphere, why make the music so fucking loud? Even crowded around a little table, we kept having to say "whaaaaatt???!" to each other the entire time. Then again, my friends and I might just be old, deaf bitches.
author: Nikki H.

description: Despite the freaky weirdness of the art on the walls, the neat moroccan lighting fixtures give this lounge a warm and sultry feeling. The hipster scene can get unruly at times but just cradle that beautiful margarita in your little paw and keep looking at the lights. Grab a corner table near the front for a prime people-watching vantage point.
author: Patricia M.

description:
Pro: It's a decent casual place to huddle up for a quick date (red light is sexy and flattering), or with your crew (usually plenty of room to sit).
Con: It's a bad place to mingle/meet new people.

Pro: The soul nights are pretty solid.
Con: The soul nights elsewhere (Knockout, Elbo Room, Edinburgh etc.) are usually better.

Pro: The velvet paintings are fun. 
Con: The restrooms are terrifying.

Pro: You never have to worry about how you look/are dressed here.
Con: The guys who hit on you there usually look (and talk) like contestants from MTV's The Pick-Up Artist.

Pro: Drinks are strong-like, real strong-and happy hour prices are extraordinary.
Con: It always smells like farts (what is the deal!?).

So there you have it.
author: Stephanie P.

description: Went there to meet some business associates the other day.  I do not go to bars much so I don't have lots to compare this place to, but this place was packed with people of all ages ....the staff was nice and friendly, the music was good and the atmosphere is really San Francisco.  A  fun place and a must stop in The Mission.
author: Edward P.

description: A pretty cool bar, especially for a girl who doesn't really drink often.  It's got a dark, intimate feel for it.  The jukebox is FREE with lots of interesting choices of songs.  I got a few dirty looks from some patrons, but that won't keep me out of this place, especially if I just want to hang out with some friends.  Neat little decorations for the holidays.  Oh, and check out the 70's erotic art on the wall...damn funny.
author: Amy J.

description:
I was here one time on New Years or something and that was okay I think, but the last time - not okay.  Bartender made me a g+t with no G, wtf?

 I could tell from the first sip that there was no gin - gin has a very distinct flavor  **juniper berries. Had my date taste it.  Same thing.  No gin. So, I went back to the bar.  I knew she wasn't going to love my accusation, and I was right. 

"Raaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaawr I put so much alcohol in all my drinks."  

"Can I have a new drink? I only took a sip. Taste it."  

She refused, and I was speechless.  Wouldn't even give me my money back. I seriously only took one sip.  Guy next to me was curious so he also tried the drink - no gin. 

Thank you for the five dollar tonic water, ho.
author: Penelope W.

description:
My friends and I popped in here right after a late lunch/early dinner in the neighborhood.  It was during their happy hour (4-7pm) where all drinks are $1 off.  My friends ordered a Manhattan and I got a tequila madras.  All drinks were super strong and sooo good.  One of my friends noted that the Manhattan he received was one of the best he's ever tasted.  

The decor is awesome.  If I was a bachelor in the 70s I'd decorate my place like this...red walls, velvet couches and naked ladies on the wall.  

The waitstaff is friendly and they have good music on the jukebox.  I've never been in here past 7pm and I guess I'm glad because I've heard and read that's when the hipsters come out and ruin things.
author: Nikki M.

description:
I have been laughing at this place for about 12 years or so (ever since I turned 21). I actually never set foot in this smell hole until a few months ago. 'Lame' is the only word to describe the vibe. If you like hipster meat markets (I REALLY DON'T), then any of them are better than this one. If booby paintings are responsible for drawing a crowd or positive reviews, then it should be obvious what mentality is shared by your average Crapanova jack-off. 

Now to be fair, the barkeeps(kinda slow newbies), the booze pours, and yes the canvas tits were all fine I guess but their allure shall remain permanently masked by the fact that I just don't want to know anybody that kicks it in there. 

 Now, if you are a person who DOES waste good bar stool space at the CasaBLOWva, please don't get all butt-hurt. It isn't your fault that your mommy and daddy didn't love you or that you aren't allowed in the big girl and boy fun bars where all the nice adult people go. C'mon there Sally. Don't get all sniffily whiffawwweeh.
author: Boxxxman J.

description:
Good music, great happy hour (the pint glasses of margarita are a worthy happy hour choice), chilled vibe, paintings of glamour-pusses with their boobies out.

I like Casanova as a starting out point for the night, or to get a few happy hour drinks and catch up with a friend early on, when it's not too busy.  There's just something about how dark it is in there that makes me not want to stay too long, especially on days when it's nice out.  That's ok though, as it's in a really convenient location for going on a bar-crawl!
author: Melanie B.

description:
Casanova used to be near and dear to my heart, as it was one of the first bars I got to know after moving to the City and the Mission a few years ago. I was there on a saturday night a couple weeks ago, and my negative experience is still resonating. 

It was 1:30AM when last call was made. We all found it odd that they were doing last call 30 minutes before closing time. But okay whatever, thanks for the warning. At 1:39AM an employee started walking around telling everyone it was time to go. I asked him what time Casanova closed and he said "We close now". hmm funny, i thought 2AM was closing time? I was offended that I wasn't given a straight up answer. And they obviously were trying to close early so they could go home. A total No-No in my book, especially on a saturday night when the place is packed. 

He came over to our table and addressed us again saying we had to leave. We had friends in the bathroom so they let us stay for a second.  Minutes later a female bartender came and took our  barely touched drinks away, all before 1:45! I could understand getting the boot if it was 2:15.....

At that point I asked the rude guy again what time they close. He said "I know what you're doing man, I know your type, time for you to leave"

What type? The type that asks when an establishment closes? The type that goes to a bar and expects to be able to drink there until somewhere around 2AM? 

So we shuffled out of the door. When we were outside my friend realized that she had been separated from her boyfriend and turned around to go back through the door. At this point the rude guy was in the doorway and pushed my friend very hard, almost knocking her on the ground. Thankfully there was the whole crowd that had just been kicked out to break her fall.

I would give this place zero stars if I could. There's no excuse for the help to be physically assaulting the customers unless said customer is throwing punches or wielding a gun. 

Of course none of us will go to Casanova again. Alot of us work in the industry as well and have shared our experience with others, encouraging them not to go to Casanova. It's a shame such a great place turned into an example of unexcusable behavior thanks to a couple of bad apple employees.
author: Bman B.

description:
Came here with some friends after a bit of tipple elsewhere.  The interior has a nice mix of Spanish and Arab (Moorish overall?) influences with plenty of comfy couches and tables.  Music was very good, great selection of older classics that everyone knows and loves, basically.  Part of the crowd was 'the Mission hipster' distilled, wearing the the usual vintage clothes and acting 'too cool to look happy.'  Thankfully, there was some other interesting people mixed in, ranging from the slutty blond in the tiny dressed basically giving lap dances to a section of the bar, to the just-out-drinking group that basically put no effort into their evening garb (myself included).

A big plus was the acceptance of the fact that, as a lounge, the music should be background loud, not head-hammeringly loud.  Conversation was easily possible, and I was thankful for that.

A nice place overall, and I would come back.  As an aside, I wear a fedora or similarly proper cap to keep my head warm when I walk home, to keep the sun out of my eyes during the day, and because it reminds me of my grandfather who gave me my nice hats.  Usually I am the only one donning a proper hat like that, but here I saw 5 other people with fedoras.  Don't know what that means, but thought I'd mention it.
author: Eric M.

description:
I really think you need to view casanova in context.  its a hipster bar, so its gonna be full of hipsters, and you are gonna have to listen to hipster music.  its pretty divey, and yet, comfortable.

the drinks are inexpensive, the bartenders reasonably friendly, and the seats are real comfy.

i can't really complain
author: Steve S.

description:
I've heard this place is awful on the weekends, but Elaine and I went last Wednesday and it was *fantastic*.  The drinks were reasonably priced (happy hour), the decor is priceless, and the bartender was friendly.  The whole place seemed populated by hipsters, though, and I'd rather see more 1960s and 1970s fanatics in there.

I particularly love the velvet paintings and glass grape lamps hanging from the ceiling.  The stage setup is the best I've ever seen.

It's very easily BART accessible.
author: Normal O.

description:
I would give it a four stars on the weekedays and 2 or 3 on the weekends. 

On weekdays, there are always enough people to keep it lively and the couches are awesome. The drinks are relatively inexpensive and the bartenders are nice and easy-going. 

On weekends, I think there is some sort of Blondie's spill-over effect that ends up making this bar crowded with obnoxious people. Good luck getting a drink there on the weekends.
author: Jen M.

description:
I have been reading the reviews here and apparently, this is a hipster bar. Well, the multiple times I've been here, I never seem to really run into any hipsters. They're always over at delirium. You get a much older crowd here, so instead of early 20s, late 20s to mid 30s. There really isn't a lot of interesting people here when I have gone but I'm a fan of this place because our bartender was really nice to my buddy. My buddy had flown in from the east coast and thought it was a good idea to walk through mission late at night to get to his hostel. Bartender suggested he get a cab because it just wasn't a good idea. 

And my friend who was jet-lagged kept on falling asleep on the couch. Bouncer could have kicked us out but he just kept on telling my friend to stop it. Well, who told you to get such comfy couches?
author: James L.

description:
Long pours in a short glass, after???? I was on my ass.

And,  Iam sure there was a fair amount of boobage shown.
author: Douggers M.

description:
Casanova is one of the better bars in the Mission, which clearly isn't saying much since almost all bars in the Mission are jam packed with suck hipsters. Nevertheless, they have a nice assortment of beers and if you avoid Fri/Sat night you can have a good time with friends. 

The jukebox is a bit over-the-top and needs to refrain from trying so hard.

The clientele is clearly not Casanova's fault, but it'd be oh so nice if the fools in tight jeans and absurd shades would just move to Menlo Park or something.
author: K F.

description:
i agree with lucky lauren s, this bar is kind of cool on a low key, not so busy day.. good to stop through and grab a drink, but come night fall, this place gets way to insanely packed. I mean business is good, if you can be lucky enough to land a table you are money, but otherwise be prepared to have people try to ram right through you... i dont know what the max capacity is, but just because they deem you can fit X amount of people in a place, doesnt mean you have to take it to the max.. its down right uncomfy..

plus they never seem to know how to make so-co bombs and dont want to be told how to do it so they give the evil eye!
author: jamie z.

description:
We walked up and down the neighboring streets passing bar after bar looking for a place that actually had patrons, wasn't pitch black, and maybe, just maybe even felt welcoming. 
We were getting discouraged until someone said "oh wait, Cassanova!"

It was crowded for a Wednesday night, which felt nice. Although it did take an unusually long time for us to get drinks. And once I decided what I wanted then didn't have peach Schnapps for the first drink, or cream for a White Russian but I was made an awesome and strong Mudslide. 

As it got later the music seemed to be getting louder and I couldn't really hear anyone in my party tell stories anymore, it was at this point we figured we should call it quits while we were ahead. 

Ive always wanted a place that gave me an excuse to buy awesome yet possibly tasteless and showy decor items, Cassanova would be that place; velvet paintings of naked women and lovely, 1960s lamps paired with varying couches of fabrics you wouldn't want to see in day light. 

Its a bar with a good, young feel and crowd that has good drinks in a popular and accessible spot of the city.
author: Jen R.

description: Last night was hair metal night, apparently. Casanova is hyper and fun, and cheap (PBR!). Give me more tequila, though! Come on, don't be stingy! It has some cool lights and tables, and heavens me the erotic paintings.
author: Joanna M.
